partisan_rally_speeches.title: Watch Ryan Moore's full speech at the 2016 Democratic National Convention
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: My name is Ryan Moore from South Sioux City, Nebraska. My family began our friendship with Hillary over 20 years ago. Back then, she was first lady, fighting for healthcare reform. As a person with a rare form of dwarfism, my family knew that my life was going to be filled with surgeries and hospital visits. So, we were grateful when Hillary asked to hear our story. For me, quality, affordable healthcare was more than a privilege, and even more than a right. It was an absolute necessity. I'm thankful that she's kept up to fight over the years, and I'm honored to call her my friend. Here's what I can tell you for my years knowing Hillary Clinton. She's compassionate. Every time I see Hillary, she remembers meaningful details about my life, sometimes from years earlier. When I first met her, I was seven years old and wearing a back brace. Two years later, when I saw her again, she patted my back and said, you don't have a back brace anymore. I could not believe that she remembered that. A lot of people wouldn't have. A lot of people wouldn't have, but she did. She's thoughtful. Every time I have a big operation coming up, I always receive a note from Hillary, full of encouragement and kindness. She lifts my spirits. She helps me believe that everything is going to be all right. Most of all, she's genuine. Something happens when you meet Hillary. No matter how busy she is, and how pretty sure she's always really busy, she makes you feel like the most important person in her day. She blocks everything else out and just focuses on me, how my job is going, how I'm feeling. She really cares. And I know that so many people who have met her over the years say the exact same thing. I wish everyone could get to know Hillary's heart like I have. She always looks out for the little guy, no pun intended. And that's why I'm so proud to support Hillary Clinton as our next president. Thank you.

But I do understand that people are tired of hearing about the lawsuits. But it is important that people are able to bring their concerns forward and that we answer them. And I am all for that. That people have a right to have their grievances heard. Now the thing that you heard me say here today is for example the lawsuit, the Hille assault lawsuit was filed my second week in office. And it was relating to promotional practices that occurred before I was county executive. And it was filed in the court of law and I think that is where it should be resolved. I think what people are tired of is a press conference every week to hash out the details of a lawsuit when the lawsuit should be resolved in court. Is filed in court appropriately so and it should be resolved in court. As I think the public is fatigued of every week turning on the television and hearing on the news or in a paper something more about the lawsuit that they know should be resolved there. So we want the lawsuit, we want the concern to be addressed. I will address the concern. The county has a responsibility to answer. If there is some discrimination that is occurring we want to address it. If there are practices that need to be changed we have a police reform commission that is reviewing all of our policies and practices and we will address whatever the concerns all but I think the public is fatigued of every week. We can't resolve personal issues at press conferences nor should we. It's not the appropriate forum for it. We can't resolve lawsuits at press conferences. It's not the appropriate forum. I think that's what the public is fatigued of. I think that's what the public is fatigued of.

I'm running for Senate to be a voice for families like the ones I grew up with here. Angela also Brooks is on a mission to be Maryland's next US Senator. The 52 year old Prince George's County Executive and mother has mounted an aggressive campaign. So far, she's racked up more than 80 endorsements, including support from Senator Chris Van Holland and Congressman Stenny Hoyer. Recent campaign filing show also Brooks has raised nearly $2 million. It's the most money raised by campaign contributions. Why do you feel that you should be the next Senator for Maryland? I believe very firmly that Marylanders deserve a Senator who not only fights hard for them, but who understands them and shares the concerns of everyday hard working families. I've spent my career focused on families, the issues of growing economic opportunity. What do you think is about your message that's really resonating with people? I think voters want someone who share their lived experience. A person like myself who is not only raising as a working mom, a teenage daughter, but I am also working as a part of that sandwich generation to care for my aging parents. This helps me to understand so clearly the issues of everyday families. Also Brooks isn't alone in her quest to replace Senator Cardin. Others have declared including Congressman David Trone, Montgomery County Councilman Will Joando, telecom executive Juan Dominguez, and activist Jerome Segal, Trone Missile Funded. He's the co-owner of Total Wine and More and has both infused and spent millions of dollars so far. Do you feel that Congressman David Trone really is your primary challenger in this race? I've been well noted that I have a person in the race who says he's going to spend $50 million of his own money in this race. Raising money is important. Being able to communicate is important, but I think what is most important is focusing on the issues again that everyday families care about living in a place that is safe. True economic opportunity, creating jobs and increasing income. You have a close relationship with the Vice President. I wonder what advice she's given you about your campaign, what to do, and maybe what things to stay away from. The Vice President really has been a great friend and mentor. She helped me as state's attorney. Many of the restorative justice programs and we were able to implement. We learned about through the work that she was doing. One of the things that she has some advice she's given that I've used recently is I said to her, you know, what do you wish you had known? And she said she wished that she had journal more. To really document the beautiful experiences that she had had all along the way. And so I have done that in this campaign for the first time. Also Brooks were to win the primary and then the general election. She would be Maryland's first black U.S. Senator and the third black woman to hold a seat in the body. Do those distinctions matter to you? The historic nature of this race is not lost on me. But I can tell you that I know that voters will consider a number of factors. I think gender will be one of the factors that they consider maybe raised. But I can tell you that there will be other factors that voters consider, especially experience. And when they consider experience, I think they'll find that I have the best experience of anyone in this race. Larry Miller, W USA 9.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Tammy Baldwin victory speech
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: A senator who will stand on the side of the middle class. A senator who will wake up every morning and fight for the middle class. They've told me that they want an economy in which everyone plays by the same rules and everyone does their fair share. They've told me that they want a level playing field. One where China can't cheat our workers and millionaires can't dodge taxes and Wall Street can't catch our economy with the risky gambling. They've told me that they want to pay down our debt without short-changing our future. They've told me that they want to be able to rely on the guarantees of Medicare and Social Security not just today but for future generations. Most of all, they've told me that the special interests have too much power in Washington and it's time for the people's voice to be heard. And it's time for the people's voice to be heard. Well, the people's voice was heard tonight Wisconsin and Tom January, your voice will be heard in the United States Senate. I am honored and humbled and grateful and I'm ready to get to work. I'm ready to stand with President Barack Obama. I'm ready to fight for Wisconsin's middle class. Now, I am well aware that I will have the honor to be Wisconsin's first woman, U.S. Senator. And I am well aware that I will be the first openly gay member. But I didn't run to make history. I ran to make a difference. A difference in the lives of families struggling to find work and pay the bills. A difference in the lives of students worried about debt. And seniors worried about their retirement security. A difference in the lives of veterans who fought for us and need someone fighting for them and their families. A difference in the lives of entrepreneurs trying to build a business and working people trying to build some economic security. But in choosing me to tackle those challenges, the people of Wisconsin have made history. And I can't tell you how grateful I am for the trust that you've placed in me. And all I can do is work as hard as I can to keep that trust. I know that many of the people listening to this speech tonight may not have voted for me. But I want you to know that I will stand up for you. And I ask you to work with me to move our state forward. And I want to thank you for your support. Here is the promise I want to make you. I will be a senator for all of Wisconsin. I will be a senator from both political parties and all across the ideological spectrum. And I have a lot of good examples to follow. One is Herb Cole. You know that when he first ran for the U.S. Senate, his slogan was nobody's senator but yours. And of course of his service, that slogan became a title, one that he has earned every day that he has served the state of Wisconsin. I am so grateful to have had his support throughout this campaign and humbled to carry his deep commitment to public service. I also want to thank Tommy Thompson for his life in public service. And before I do, I would like you to indulge me in an acknowledgement on a very personal level. I just got off the phone with him. He was very cordial and congratulated me and wished me well and wished all of us well. I want to tell you a quick little story about Tommy Thompson on a very personal level. I still remember the first time I ever met Tommy. I was 30 years old and a freshman member of the Wisconsin Assembly. He was greeting new members of the legislature at the governor's mansion. We didn't talk politics. I explained to the governor that I was Joe Baldwin's daughter and that I had never met him before my father passed away. Tommy's face lit up. He had known my father in college and he would delight in sharing some small remembrance every time I saw him. And that meant the world to me. Tommy and I didn't always agree. In fact, in this campaign we didn't agree on much. But there can be no doubt that he shares my love and all of our love for Wisconsin. And tonight I want to reach out to his supporters and ask them to join me in standing up for our belief that we are all in this together. Now, make no mistake. I am a proud Wisconsin progressive. And I, which means I believe in holding the powerful accountable. I believe in fair play. And I believe that when people are struggling, you don't talk down to them. You help lift them up. And I believe and I believe in Wisconsin's workers and a work ethic that I will fight for every day. But I also believe that we can only move forward if we move forward together. This has been an incredible journey. One that has shown me the best that our state has to offer. I've watched Wisconsin workers put the Made in America label on boots for our soldiers in Maryland, on ships made in Marinette, and engines made in Baloid. I've met with potato farmers in Clover. I've eaten while I in Fondelac. And the best cream puffs in the world at the state fair in West Dallas. And I am grateful to so many people tonight. I want to thank the people of the second congressional district for giving me the honor of serving you for the last 14 years. And I want to congratulate Mark Pocan, who will give you a perfect job representing. It has been a privilege to serve in the House of Representatives. And I had a hard working dedicated team of congressional staff who do incredible work in my name, but on your behalf. I have led by my dear friend and chief of staff, Bill Marott. I want to recognize these amazing people. I am grateful for all the elected officials and public servants who stood with me throughout this campaign. And in particular, I want to single out one more. I want to thank you for the last 14 months. I have never been a part of a campaign organization as amazing as this one. And I want to thank my friend and campaign manager, Karen Johansson. I want to thank her for helping me build this team of determined, inspirational and incredible staff, supporters, volunteers. It has been incredible. And I am grateful for the campaign. Now, you've all heard a lot about my grandparents who raised me. And especially my grandmother, she was born in 1906 before women had the right to vote and got to live to see her granddaughter elected to the House of Representatives. I know she would be proud tonight. I am happy and so fortunate to have with me tonight my mother Pam. Now, among all the things I could tell you about her, she had the prophetic wisdom to name me Tammy. And how could she have known that one day there would be headlines reading Tammy versus Tommy? I also am joined this evening by my aunts and uncle, Sarah, Melinda and Guy. And I just want to thank my family for their love, support and encouragement. So tonight a long journey comes to an end, but we know our work is just beginning. And whether you voted for me or not, whether tonight you're celebrating a victory or dealing with a defeat. I hope that when we wake up tomorrow morning, we are ready to work. Ready to fight. Ready to fight for our middle class. Ready to keep our promises to our seniors. Ready to have a level playing field for our workers. Ready to make sure that everyone has a fair shot. Ready to make our country stronger, more prosperous and more equal. Ready to do what Wisconsinites have done for generations. Stand together and move forward. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: 2016 MOSES Conference: Senator Baldwin's Address
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: We have been very blessed to have a wonderful senator in the state of Wisconsin. Her name is Tammy Baldwin. And she has been an advocate for a very important part of agriculture. And that is the promotion of public plant breeding, helping the land grant universities move forward with basically retaking over their space in producing seeds that are regionally adapted and that are open for public use. That has kind of diminished over the past few years. And she has helped us a lot by working in her place on the Senate Agricultural Appropriations Committee by putting language directing the USDA to put more money into research in this important area. In addition, she is a wonderful place when I go to Washington, D.C. to feel that I'm walking into an office with a friendly face and a wonderful demeanor. And I also know that she works really hard. And if Tammy is going to say that she's going to do something, she's going to get it done. So with that, I'd like to have our senator from Wisconsin, Tammy Baldwin, come up and give you a little address. So, well, good afternoon. What an honor it is to join you at the 27th annual Moses Conference. It is also an honor to have gotten to watch the proceedings. And I want to just add my words of gratitude to you, Fay, for your remarkable work and the remarkable legacy that you are leaving. And I'm going to take you at your word because I hope to come back again. I hope to see you here even in a different capacity. Thank you. So, I just want to say that it is a deep honor to get the opportunity to represent a state with such a deep and enduring agricultural innovation tradition. In fact, our grown-in Wisconsin economy, the sector contributes $88.3 billion in economic activity and provides about 413,000 jobs, employing almost one out of nine people in the state of Wisconsin. The Moses attendees here today include some of the pioneers of the organic and sustainable agriculture movements. These are folks who remember the time before the organic seal. The time before we invested in dedicated organic research, before organic was one of the fastest growing parts of the agricultural industry. Those farmers and agricultural experts poured countless hours into and created the bold vision that there need to be viable markets for the organic industry, and also the growing organic agriculture could be a critical part of keeping families on the farm and keeping many small farms on our beautiful landscape, and keeping our rural communities and quality of life strong because of that. Here today, we also have some of our newest farmers, and probably many people who are thinking about a life in organic agriculture. We want to hear from these new and aspiring farmers, hear about their challenges, hear about what helps them succeed so that we can continue to support this vibrant sector of our agriculture industry, and rural communities that need young farmers to keep them strong. Organic is one of the fastest growing sectors of the agricultural economy nationwide, and over the past few decades, organic production has grown rapidly here in the Badger State. With nearly 1200 certified organic farmers and handlers, Wisconsin ranks second to only the state of California in the number of organic farms. But as you all know, we have work to do in order to move forward. We need to help future organic farmers get their start and ensure that organic farmers have the tools that they need to succeed. And it's why I have fought and will continue to fight for increased investments for the organic transitions program. This program supports the development and implementation of research in higher education and extension programs to improve the competitiveness of organic livestock and crop producers, and help offset the costs of transitioning to organic production for individual farmers. The Dairy Grazing Apprenticeship Program is also a wonderful Wisconsin innovation, and I have advocated for this program, because it's based on a great coalition of dairy grazers across Wisconsin, who have worked to make dairy grazing not only feasible, but also respected as a growing part of our dairy industry. Now the apprenticeship program pairs young aspiring farmers with farmers nearing retirement to help with farm transitions and help the next generation get its start. I'm also proud to have been a strong supporter of the Farm Bill's conservation programs, including the Conservation Stewardship Program and the Environmental Quality Incentive Program. And the creation of better risk management tools, including crop insurance for organic crops. I have taken on these fights and been a voice for you in Washington because I understand that in Wisconsin farming is not just a part of the economy, it's a way of life that must be strengthened and protected. You represent an ethic of caring for our land and providing healthy food for our families and our neighbors. Well, organic farmers don't use the same tools to respond to farming challenges that conventional farmers use, such as chemical pesticides and fertilizers and certain seeds. Organic farmers are extremely innovative in finding ways to manage pests and crop issues and raise livestock in an ecologically sensitive way. What that means, of course, is that not all agricultural research is useful to organic producers. We need to increase investments in organic agriculture to help producers increase yields, improve disease resistance and deal with our changing climate. So I am pressing the USDA to invest in publicly available plant and animal breeds that will provide more options for organic producers and respond to both the challenges that you face today and the growing markets that you cater to. In particular, I am fighting to ensure that these public research investments are delivering research results that can be directly used by farmers to meet the challenges that you face now with solutions that you can use now. In Wisconsin, we are lucky to have innovators in sustainable agricultural systems. For many years, they have pioneered solutions to the challenges that face organic producers. I strongly support increased investments in sustainable agriculture research and extensions program because it provides funding to support this work, to address difficulties that new farmers face and help farmers innovate and share best practices. From sustainable agriculture systems and dynamic education for our beginning, farmers time and time again, Moses has brought together those who carry on our state's history of farming with great pride. I am proud to be your partner in the United States Senate as we continue to move together, to work together, to build a grown-in Wisconsin economy. I know you are not all from Wisconsin, but I have to say I am partial here and keep all of our rural communities growing and strong. I look forward to continuing our work together and I want to just again thank you so honestly and deeply for inviting me to join the conference today. I know there is only a few hours left, but please enjoy every second that remains. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Baldwin Floor Speech on Defense Spending
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Thank you, Mr. President. It is no secret that we are living in a dangerous time, and we face a variety of threats to our security at home and abroad. We all agree that we need to make investments in a strong military to protect and defend our national security. We have also come together in agreement on the need to take on our national security challenges and our challenges here at home in a balanced way. The bipartisan budget agreement that we passed into law last year was far from perfect, but it provided much needed certainty for our economy by preventing the ongoing threats of a government default or a government shutdown. It restored investments in both our national and our economic security, ensuring that every dollar of investment in defense was matched by a dollar of investment in a stronger economy and a stronger middle class. A balanced approach has served us well. It was a necessary compromise grounded in fairness that should guide our bipartisan work going forward. I understand that the Chairman would like to give the Defense Department $18 billion more than they currently have from the American taxpayers. But I also know that the American people need stronger investments in the challenges that they face each and every day just trying to get ahead. If we're going to spend more on our military than it's only fair that we also invest more in education, in job training, and workforce readiness to raise incomes and create a stronger economy for all. If we're going to spend more on the Pentagon than it's only fair, we also invest more in putting people to work and rebuilding our crumbling infrastructure and transportation and water infrastructure. I also know that we have unfinished business in the Congress to bolster our vulnerable cybersecurity infrastructure and to boost TSA security and to better support our law enforcement needs. We also have a responsibility to act on the public health crisis posed by Zika. We simply must do more and approve the necessary funding to prevent, detect, and respond to this serious and dangerous threat. And we need to provide relief to the people in Flint, Michigan who are still suffering from the impacts of lead contamination. I understand the military has asked for more helicopters and more fighter jets. But I also know that the American people need Washington to be stronger partners in the fights that we are confronting in communities across our country today. That's why I am pleased to support Senator Reid's amendment to invest $18 billion to help our middle class to keep our country safe and to respond to the Zika virus and lead contamination and heroin and opioids and the crisis that we are facing with drug abuse throughout our nation. As I have traveled Wisconsin, it is clear that we face an opioid and heroin epidemic. And I know that many of my colleagues here in the Senate face that same crisis in their home states. In Wisconsin, it is a big problem and it demands a bold response from Washington. We are in the midst of a crisis that is touching far too many across our state. I have heard stories from family members who have tragically lost loved ones to addiction. And I have heard from people who are on the path of recovery. At one of my community meetings in Pihuahki, a father came up to me to courageously share a story of tragically losing his youngest son to addiction a couple of years ago right after Christmas. And recently I heard from Leonard from Colfax, Wisconsin, whose grandson Nathan was killed in a car accident when he was just 16 years old. The driver of the other car was under the influence of heroin at the time. I have also heard from a mother from South Milwaukee whose son suffered from addiction for 20 years. While he is now in recovery at one point, she found him unconscious from a heroin overdose on their bathroom floor. Another mother from McWanago wrote to tell me that her own son's life was saved by paramedics who administered the drug naloxone during his overdose, allowing him to survive. The message is clear, families simply can't afford to wait any longer for help from Washington. It should not be easier for Wisconsinites to get their hands on opioids or heroin than it is for them to get treatment for their addiction. As we consider today increasing our spending for the military, let us not forget American law enforcement, first responders, health care providers, and citizens fighting on the front lines to combat our opioid and heroin crisis. Let us not forget those struggling to get sober and to stay healthy. As communities continue to confront this epidemic on a daily basis, Washington needs to step up and needs to be a strong partner with state and local and nonprofit efforts. The first place we can start is by making emergency investments for prevention, crisis intervention, treatment, and recovery efforts. I was proud to support by partisan legislation that provides this funding because these resources are vital as we continue to respond to this national emergency. Unfortunately, this funding was blocked by congressional Republicans. This epidemic knows no political party and it should be an issue that unites us all. We must do more because fighting this nationwide epidemic is a shared responsibility. Everyone has a role to play in addressing this crisis and Congress should be no exception. The communities we represent need the resources necessary to win this fight. I know from talking to people I work for in Wisconsin that the opioid and heroin epidemic is a problem that neither law enforcement nor the health care system can tackle alone. The federal government can't solve this problem by itself just as we can't expect state and local communities to address it by themselves. Together, we must continue our fight and rise to this challenge. Let's work together to help our communities recover from this epidemic and stay healthy. The Senate will soon vote on the red amendment. This amendment would provide $1.1 billion to respond to the opioid and heroin crisis. The amendment would invest a total of $18 billion, equal to the amount of funding that my Republican colleague, Chairman McCain, is proposing to spend on the Department of Defense. The vote is about fairness and priorities. I believe that if we are going to provide more funding to the Pentagon, we should also invest in our middle class. Ensure our security here at home and step up to the plate and provide the resources Americans need to respond to the serious emergencies that they face here at home. Mr. President, I yield back and I would suggest the absence of a quorum. The clerk called the roll. Mr. Alexander.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Baldwin / Sanders Campaign Rally
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands one nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all. I'm going to give you a round of applause. I'm going to give you a round of applause. I'm going to give you a round of applause. Wow, what an incredible crowd. How's everybody doing today? Here you have a nurse who supports gutting pre-existing conditions for everybody. You know, I have cancer. That's a pre-existing condition. That hits pretty close to home. You know, but Tammy Baldwin, she's going to fight to protect those pre-existing conditions. She's going to improve our healthcare, not destroy it. We need to keep Tammy exactly where she is. And a huge thank you to Senator Bernie Sanders. Bernie has supported our campaign since the beginning, which has honestly meant so much. We had a couple of events already, and I was thinking up to today, it's great having an event with Bernie, but today we actually have two events, one here and then one down in Kenosha. I got a phone call from his campaign, and they asked me if I would speak at his rally when he's running for president. That really set him apart from other candidates for me. Not only that, not only that, but his campaign staff wanted to know if there was a picket line. And he continues every single day to be a part of a working people. Both in his work every day as senator, fighting tirelessly for $15 an hour, and Medicare for all, and in his support from my campaign, and energizing Wisconsin voters to take back our state. And while I may have been active in Wisconsin politics for a few years, now mainly protesting like Act 10, and more recently for immigrants' rights, running for Congress really was not something I was ever on my bucket list. He wanted to repeal and replace healthcare for 23 million Americans. We said, let's repeal and replace him. When I returned from my service in the Army, I worked two full-time jobs, and I didn't have health insurance. So when I was diagnosed with cancer, I had no way to cover the costs. The financial burden was insurmountable, and I had to declare bankruptcy because of my medical bills. I know that my story resonates with countless people because it's their story too. Soon after, I started an apprenticeship as an ironworker. And I'll work an iron, it's a tough job, but it was also that that would help me get out of debt, and that was my ticket to the middle class. It allowed me to provide for healthcare for my son. It gave us both good health insurance and allowed me entry into the middle class. But sadly, too many good-paying union jobs are being outsourced. Right here in Wisconsin, at home, and all across the country. That's why I'm here. That's why I keep fighting. For all of us. With your help and the help from people all across this country, we were able to repeal Paul Ryan. But make no mistake, his hand-picked replacement is just as bad as he is. His hand-picked replacement is a corporate attorney who has made his money outsourcing good-paying Wisconsin jobs. He's supported the tax scam, and he's not going to protect Medicare and Social Security. Bottom line, he's a corporate lawyer who doesn't know what it's like to fall on hard times. What it means to live in poverty, and how hard it is to make ends meet when his party keeps putting profits over people. Now my opponent refers to me as Radical Randy. My 12-year-old son thinks that's kind of cool. You know, but all things being said, I don't think it's radical to demand that everybody has access to healthcare. I don't think it's radical to demand that we protect good-paying American jobs, and we start exporting cars, not jobs. Just remember, after Election Day, there's not going to be any phone calls to call people for help. We need to win this November. Next, I have a great privilege to introduce the next speaker, my friend Mandela Barnes. Mandela was one of the few early endorsements that we endorsed each other, and it was easy. It was an easy thing to do. Since being elected State Representative, I remember seeing him beating the Sun up at the crack of dawn to go stand up on behalf of Walmart workers to make sure that they would get $15 an hour. So we have a thing, Randy Bryce. Think about how privileged we are to have Randy Bryce right here in the state of Wisconsin. And you don't have to look much further than rooms like this to know that people are frustrated and tired of eight years of divide and conquer under Governor Scott Walker. Unfortunately, people have not seen any wage increases. Our environment has been disregarded. Our schools have been defunded. That was then, this is now. And that is why we are running this race across the entire state. We are not just campaigning in every county. But we are making sure that we show up in every community. To make sure that people are heard. To make sure that the voices of people who have been forgotten who have been left behind by government will no longer be forgotten. And they will be heard in the Evers Barnes administration. So I say all this to say that I know people look at Tony Evers and myself and they look at those two young guys. Just getting across the state, campaigning and having a great time doing Facebook Live videos. But it is so much more than that. And we know that this campaign won't just be about everything that Governor Walker has done wrong. We only have 15 days. It is just not enough to talk about all the things that are wrong. This campaign is about restoring hope and opportunity to everybody in this state. It is about making sure that we provide access to quality and affordable health care. It means that we take the Medicaid expansion on the first day in office. It means that we work to create a badger care public option so that we can have health care for all for everybody in the state of Wisconsin. And as Randy said before me is a cancer survivor. And frankly, if my opponent had been in the United States Senate last year, we would have seen her be the deciding vote to take people's health care away. But that's not all. Over her 16-year record as a politician in Wisconsin, she has consistently stood with the big insurance companies. She even opposed a bill that required insurance coverage for oral chemotherapy. Now, who does that? I was not sent to Washington to take people's health care away. That's right. And I believe that every Wisconsinite deserves affordable high quality health care. And this fight, many of you know, this fight is personal for me. When I was a child, I had a very serious childhood illness at age 9. I was in the hospital for three months. And my grandparents who raised me, found out that their insurance family insurance coverage didn't cover a grandchild. You know, in the fine print, I wasn't a legal dependent. This happens throughout our nation. But you know, after I recovered, they said, let's fix this. Let's get her insurance that we know will cover her. Well, I'll tell you, I wasn't a very attractive candidate for insurance after three months in the hospital because I had this label, child with a pre-existing health condition. You know, it's why I entered public service and why I fought so hard to make sure that no one is ever again denied coverage because of a pre-existing health condition. And I pushed, I pushed to make sure that young people could stay on their parents' health insurance until they're 26 years old. And now millions more young people have insurance coverage. You know, health care is on the ballot this year. And we can't let my opponent and her special interest friends take our health care away from us. That's right. But let's also look at another issue. That tax plan that special corporate interest pushed through Congress last year. You know, my opponent backed that plan where 83% of the benefits go to the top 1% of individuals and large multinational corporations on the corporate side. You know, it benefited companies like Exxon and Wells Fargo and drug manufacturers like Pfizer as if they weren't already having massive enough profits. So you know, one company, one corporation, Exxon Mobile will get a bigger tax break in the first year of this tax plan than every Wisconsin individual and family combined. It makes no sense. Frankly, if that tax plan had of sent 83% of its benefits to hardworking families and middle class families, it would have gotten my vote. But instead, my opponent only wants to reward her corporate interest friends. She wants to pay for this new tax law. Get this by putting social security and Medicare and Medicaid on the table. And that's the difference. That's the choice that voters face this year. My opponent has sold out to Wisconsin and national corporate special interests. She does their bidding. Meanwhile, I will stand up to anyone, whatever the cost to do right by Wisconsin. And... But we have... We have a job to do. We can't let my opponent and her special interests backers run roughshod over Wisconsin. We need to rise up and speak out and demand that Washington starts working for Wisconsin. And I need you all. I need you all to be engaged in the remaining days of this fight. Each and every one of you can and will make a difference. And it's going to take all of us. Powerful special interests have sunk millions of dollars trying to defeat me here in Wisconsin. Over $14 million to date. But I have something that they don't. And that's all of you. That's all of you. So... We saw... We saw in the health care fight the impact that you can have. You own that win. And that's what it's going to take to win this election. It's up to all of us to speak out. It's up to all of us to stand up. And it's up to all of us to vote. You have no need to wait until November 6th to cast your vote. And if you live in Milwaukee County, pull out your phones right now. And type in www.tammybaldwin.com slash early vote. And that's going to bring you to a site that tells you where you can early vote. And when you can early vote. And including the fact that one of those early vote sites is right across the street. Which gives you no excuse not to love this rally and then go out and early vote. Now look, this is so critically important. Because while there are names of candidates on the ballot, there are also deeply personal issues on the ballot. Health care is on the ballot. Pensions are on the ballot. Climate change is on the ballot. Net neutrality is on the ballot. Equality is on the ballot. And I am so grateful. I want to remind you again that, yeah, those special interests have millions of dollars, millions of millions of dollars. But you, you are the ones who are going to decide. I have the distinct honor of bringing you my friend and my colleague in the United States Senate. Please welcome Senator Bernie Sanders. Thank you. Thank you. Whoa. You know, if I were a Republican looking out in this crowd, I would be very nervous. Today we are here for some very serious business. And that serious business is re-electing my good friend, my colleague Tammy Baldwin back to the US Senate. To tell Scott Walker, it is time for him to depart. And to elect Tony Evers as governor. To elect Mandela Bonds as Lieutenant Governor. To elect Randy Bryce as the congressman from the first congressional district. And to send my old friend, when more, back to Congress for another term. Now, let me give you a brief history of US politics in recent years. Because it ain't complicated. And people saying, it's a midterm election. I don't have to vote. And they stayed home. And working people stayed home. For income people stayed home. People of color stayed home. Young people stayed home. Not this time is exactly right. And people stayed home. And right wing Republicans won sweeping victories all across this country. And the result is we now have right wing leadership in the House of Representatives led by your very own Paul Ryan. You know Paul. And in the Senate by Mitch McConnell. And that is what happens when people don't vote. In this election 2018, we have learned our lesson. We're not going to have the lowest midterm voter turnout in history. We are going to have the highest voter turnout. And I want to say this is a wonderful turnout. I see people of all ages here. But I want to say a special word to the young people. I want to say to the young people, no offense to those of us who are older. The young generation in America today is the most progressive generation in the history of this country. Your generation is the least sexist, the least racist, the least homophobic, the least bigoted generation in the history of America. And your generation cares deeply about the health of the planet and climate change. But all of that decency, all of that love, all of that concern doesn't mean anything if you don't come out to vote. And mock my words on this. If the younger generation, people on the 30 vote at the same level as the rest of the population, you will transform the United States of America. So what Tammy and Nina and everybody else, what we are asking of you, is not only to come out and vote, not only to do early voting, but do something else. And I know it may be a little bit uncomfortable, but we are living in uncomfortable times. And we got to do sometimes things that make us a little bit nervous. And that is what we have. I think we have well over 1,000 people here. It's a great turnout. And that means a thousand votes for Tammy and the other great candidates. But if each and every one of you goes out of your way and starts talking to family members and co-workers and to your neighbors and you say, you know what? I know you don't usually vote, but this election is so very important. Come on out with me. I'll walk you to the polls. In fact, I'll even cook dinner for you on election night. And if each of you do that, that 1,000 votes that I hear this afternoon suddenly becomes 4,000 votes. And let me say something about voting turnouts and democracy. And that is, you know, Tammy has run for office and been around the wild and I've been around the wild. And this is what I honestly believe. And I come from Montenegro, run for office and I have lost elections and I've won elections. But it has never, ever occurred to me to make it harder for people to vote to suppress the vote because they might vote against me. Tammy and I have conservative friends and we debate the issues. So that's fine. That's American democracy. But what is not American democracy is to do what they're doing in Georgia, to do what they're doing in North Dakota. And to in fact do what they have done in this great state over the last 10 years and that it's making harder for people to vote. And I mean this seriously. Okay, I've been in a million debates and in a million campaigns. And if candidates, if my Republican friends out there don't have the guts to defend their ideas, if the only way they think they can win elections is by suppressing the vote and making it harder for people to vote, I say to them, get out of politics and get another job. Thank you. No, no, no, no, it ain't Bernie, it is you. You are going to transform this state and you are going to transform America. And of course as you have heard me say a million times real change, not going to come from Tammy, not going to come from me, it is going to come from you, it is going to come from grassroots America. Now I am more than painfully aware that Wisconsin in the general election voted for Donald Trump, I am small margin. But I have the strong feeling that a lot of people who voted for Trump in 2016 did not know that he was a pathological liar, that he would say one thing and then do the very opposite. When Trump ran for office, some of you may recall that he told the people of Wisconsin in Vermont in America that he was going to provide health care to everybody. You remember that? Health care everybody is what he said, but when he became president, he helped lead the effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act and throw 32 million Americans off of the health care that they have. Now I want you to think about just think for one second what it would have happened if by one vote Tammy and I had not helped defeat that horrible proposal. Think about your friends, think about your friends and family members who are dealing with cancer, dealing with heart disease, dealing with diabetes, who suddenly would have lost their lifeline and their insurance. And think about how much suffering and death would have occurred. So you got a president who told people of Wisconsin, health care for everybody, but he did exactly the opposite. You have a candidate in Donald Trump when he ran for office, he said, what was right? He said, we are going to take on the pharmaceutical industry. We are going to take on the drug companies. Two years have come and gone and drug prices today are soaring and higher than they have ever been. Donald Trump said he would take on the drug companies, but he lied. During his campaign, Donald Trump said I am a different type of Republican. Paul Ryan actually, he mentioned, Paul correctly wants the cut social security Medicare and Medicaid. Not Donald Trump, I won't do that. And I say to the people of Wisconsin who voted for Trump, he lied to you because in his last budget, he proposed a trillion dollar cut to Medicaid, 500 billion dollar cut to Medicare and a 72 billion dollar cut to the social security disability fund. Just a few weeks ago, and we don't have the time to catalog all of Trump's lives, we'd be here day and night, day and night. But just a week ago, Trump gets in front of, I think it was 60 minutes and he says, you know what, there are differences of opinion about climate change. Now there are not differences of opinion. The scientific community is virtually united in telling us that climate change is real. That it is caused by human activity, that it is already causing devastating harm in this country and around the world, and this is what they also said. They said, and that is the intergovernmental panel on climate change, and it's difficult to cut carbon emissions or this planet will suffer irreparable harm for our kids and our grandchildren. And in the White House, we have a president who is working hand in glove with the fossil fuel industry more concerned about their short-term profits than the future of our planet and the health of our children. During the presidential campaign, Trump said, I am going to take on World Street and I'm going to take on the establishment, but Trump ended up appointing more billionaires, more billionaires to his administration than any other country. And I'm going to take on the president in the history of this country. You are not taking on the establishment when you appoint billionaires after billionaires and when you de-regulate many of the large banks on World Street. You are not taking on the establishment, you are part of the billionaire establishment. You know, Donald Trump likes to present himself as a tough guy. He is a very tough guy when it comes to tearing babies out of the arms of their mothers on the southern border. But he is not such a tough guy when it comes to taking on Putin. He is a tough guy when it comes to cutting health care for children not such a tough guy when it comes to the dictators in Saudi Arabia and their mother. He is a tough guy when it comes to mocking women who have been subjected to sexual assault, very tough guy, but not such a tough guy when it comes to dealing with dictators all across this world. And I want to say something about that. People in this room, people in this state, people in my state, fought and died to defend American democracy. People fought and died for people's right to vote for people's right to speak out for a free media. And we want a president of the United States to defend democracy and human rights around the world not to cuddle up with terrible dictators and murderers. And on a personal note, I want to thank the people of Wisconsin because when I ran for president in 2016, you were there. And the importance of that victory here in Wisconsin and in 21 of the states, the importance of gaining 13 million votes, the importance of winning more votes from younger people black and white and Latino and Asian American and Native American. And the importance of all of that was that we showed the world that the time is now for dealing with a corrupt economic and political system. And that together the American people are prepared to stand up for economic, social, racial and environmental justice. And the result of all of that, the important result is that ideas that are just a few years ago seem radical and extreme. And we were attacked day and night by every editorial board, writer in America, and by the establishment, all of those so-called radical ideas are now strongly supported by the American people. Thank you, Wisconsin. Three years ago, we said that in Wisconsin over month in America, if you work 40 hours a week, you're not going to live in poverty. We're going to raise that minimum wage to a living wage, 15 bucks an hour. And guess what, all over America, cities and states, and by the way, Amazon now paying 15 bucks an hour. And we said that it is absurd that in America, eight women are making 80 cents on the dollar compared to men, we're going to have pay equity, equal pay for equal work. And we said that in this moment in history, all of our young people and people who are not so young, have the right to get a higher education regardless of their income. And what we said, we said that if this country is going to do well economically in a competitive global economy, we are going to make public colleges and universities tuition free and lower student debt. And all across the country, you're seeing states and communities moving in that direction. Everybody is entitled to a higher education if they have the ability and the desire. And I don't want to see hundreds of thousands of young people denied that opportunity. And we said, we said a few years ago, something that really speaks to what we must become as a nation. We said that in America, healthcare must be a human right, not a privilege. And we said that there is something wrong about a dysfunctional healthcare system in which 30 million people have no health insurance and many of you are underinsured. A system in which we pay the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs. A system which enables us to be the only major country on earth, not the guarantee healthcare to all people. And what we said is this country must move to a Medicare for all single payer program. And guess what? With Tammy's support and with the support of a number of members of the Senate, the last poll that I saw on that issue has 70% of the American people supporting Medicare for all. And on and on it goes, many of those issues that we talked about are now kind of mainstream issues. And we're making real progress on that and we should all be proud of that. But when we talk about Trump, I want to say one more point. And that is yes, Tammy and I disagree with Trump on his economic policies, on his climate change policies. But there is a deeper level that we have very, very strong offense to what he is doing. And that is the following. Throughout the history of this country, all of you know that good people have put their lives on the line to fight against all forms of discrimination. From the days of the first settlers coming here, we all know the terrible things that were done to Native Americans. We all know about the abomination of slavery and racism and segregation. We know that a hundred years ago today, women in America did not have the right to vote. We know about all of the ugliness that was pushed on the GLGBT community. We know about the religious bigotry, the prejudices against Catholics and Italians and Irish and Jews. We know all of that history. But we also know something else that over those hundreds of years, good people, brave people, put their lives on the line to understand that we are the people of the world. And that we are a common, you not humanity, that no matter where we were born, what the color of our skin is, what our sexual orientation may be, we are one people. And virtually every president in recent history has understood that his function was to bring people together. That's what you do when you're president of the United States. But now we have a president who, for cheap political reasons, thinks that he can win votes by dividing us up by getting one group of people to hate another group. And I say this from the bottom of my heart to Donald Trump. This country has struggled with discrimination and racism and sexism and homophobia for too long. Mr. Trump, we are not going backwards. We are going forwards. So brothers and sisters, right now we've got two weeks to an election. Let's do it. Let's tell Trump and his friends, it's still Trump and Walker and all of these guys, that we want a government and an economy based on justice. We want a government and an economy that represents all of us and not the one percent. And we are going to begin the process of making that happen today and through tomorrow and the next day until November 6th. Let us have a huge vote of turnout. Thank you all very much. Thank you. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: I'm happy to hear of your focus on our American Samoa Constitution. It's an important document. This is a great topic for you to study, and I know you'll find it interesting. As with any Constitution, it's deliberately difficult to change. The reason is that a Constitution is meant to be a rock of stability. It ensures that our laws and the rights of people cannot suddenly change direction beyond the confines of what the Constitution allows. So American Samoa has a Constitution. Under it we have major differences from the other territories. For instance, the way we select our senators in our land tenure system. These are unique to us in all of the nation. In contrast, Guam and the Virgin Islands have an organic act, and neither of them operates with a Constitution. However, every U.S. state has its own Constitution fitting in within the framework that the U.S. Constitution establishes as to what powers belong to the national government and what falls under state and local governments. American Samoa really has a one-of-a-kind relationship with the United States. It is special in several ways. That can be a difficulty because Congress tends to look at things with a one-size-fits-all approach, especially as the federal government has developed in the modern era into involvement in local schools and roads and really most parts of life, particularly providing a safety net for people when they go through a hard time. These are good things that developed over time, but can cause points where the local government and the national government have different ideas. Constitutions help resolve those situations by establishing principles that are purposefully slow to change. Our American Samoa Senate has just passed a resolution saying they'd like a change in the current U.S. public law to allow them to pursue potential changes in our territories Constitution in the future without the backstop of Congress. Change seems to come slowly, but looking back, there have been huge changes in our local government and our relationship with the United States. American Samoa became a U.S. territory by deed of session starting in 1900. The Matai or Chiefs of Trutuila seated the island through the United States in 1900. Manua followed in 1904, Swain's island joined the territory in 1925 by an act of Congress. Authority was initially placed with the U.S. Navy which oversaw the territory until 1951. The U.S. Navy was then transferred to the Department of the Interior in 1951 where it is currently. And Congress has vested the Secretary of Interior with authority to veto any local law. The people of American Samoa can have a lot of influence and self-determination when it's needed. For instance, after World War II, U.S. Department of Interior sponsored an attempt to incorporate American Samoa called the Organic Act number 4,500. This was defeated in Congress and accomplishment primarily through the efforts of American Samoa's Chiefs led by high-talking chief, Puyasasopo Mariotta. It was the efforts of these Chiefs that led to the creation of a local legislature, the American Samoa Fono. That was a huge step for our islands. In time, the Navy appointed Governor was replaced first by an appointed one. My father, Ufat Thali Peter Coleman, another major step forward to have a Governor from our own people. He helped lead the forming of a Constitution that started in 1960. The Constitution took effect on July 1, 1967, yet another big step. In 1977, along came another important step. The first constitutional elections were that year, electing my father as Governor by the choice of the people, the voters, no longer by appointment of the federal government. In Washington, only handfuls of people truly understand most of this. In fact, I'm often asked questions. Sometimes I'm even asked, when will the two Samoas merge? I answer when Canada merges with the United States. We are called American Samoa for a reason. Much like the U.S. and Canada, we share a lot of customs and language with our nearest neighbor, independent Samoa, but they are and will remain a friend and neighbor, not the same country. We are very proud of our ties to the United States. That said, we have one big difference. Unlike other U.S. territories who are U.S. citizens, American Samoans are U.S. nationals. Neither citizens nor nationals of U.S. territories vote in federal elections when residing in their territories and they pay their taxes locally, not federally. On the flip side, we do participate in most federal funding programs such as Medicaid. These differences are designed in large part to protect our land and our culture by our choice and by agreement with the federal government. Many fundamental changes to our Constitution must be approved by both houses of Congress. For instance, there is a court case in which it appears we have defeated, but that would have compelled the United States citizenship on our people. Now U.S. citizenship can be a wonderful thing, but it absolutely must be a matter of self-determination for American Samoa. How are people have to make that decision for themselves? So far, the U.S. courts have agreed to this principle in several major rulings because of this we look forward to a future that maintains the Fasamoa and that's part of the purpose of our Constitution. Enjoy your day learning about our Constitution. Soy Fua, Ma'iamanum.

It's an important document. This is a great topic for you to study, and I know you'll find it interesting. As with any Constitution, it's deliberately difficult to change. The reason is that a Constitution is meant to be a rock of stability. It ensures that our laws and the rights of people cannot suddenly change direction beyond the confines of what the Constitution allows. So, American Samoa has a Constitution. Under it, we have major differences from the other territories. For instance, the way we select our Senators in our land tenures system. These are unique to us in all of the nation. In contrast, Guam and the Virgin Islands have an organic act, and neither of them operates with a Constitution. However, every U.S. state has its own Constitution fitting in within the framework that the U.S. Constitution establishes as to what powers belong to the national government and what falls under state and local governments. American Samoa really has a one-of-a-kind relationship with the United States. It is special in several ways. That can be a difficulty, because Congress tends to look at things with a one-size-fits-all approach. Especially as the federal government has developed in the modern era into involvement in local schools and roads, and really most parts of life, particularly providing a safety net for people when they go through a hard time. These are good things that developed over time, but can cause points where the local government and the national government have different ideas. Constitution's help resolve those situations by establishing principles that are purposefully slow to change. Our American Samoa Senate has just passed a resolution, saying they'd like a change in the current U.S. public law to allow them to pursue potential changes in our territories' Constitution in the future without the backstop of Congress. Change seems to come slowly, but looking back, there have been huge changes in our local government and our relationship with the United States. American Samoa became a U.S. territory by deed of session starting in 1900. The Matai or Chiefs of Tutuila seated the island through the United States in 1900. Manua followed in 1904, Swain's island joined the territory in 1925 by an act of Congress. Authority was initially placed with the U.S. Navy which oversaw the territory until 1951. Authority was then transferred to the Department of the Interior in 1951 where it is currently, and Congress has vested the Secretary of Interior with authority to veto any local law. The people of American Samoa can have a lot of influence and self-determination when it's needed. For instance, after World War II, U.S. Department of Interior sponsored an attempt to incorporate American Samoa, called the Organic Act No. 4500. This was defeated in Congress and accomplishment primarily through the efforts of American Samoa's Chiefs, led by high-talking chief Puiasa Sopomariota. It was the efforts of these chiefs that led to the creation of a local legislature, the American Samoa Fono. That was a huge step for our islands. In time, the Navy-appointed governor was replaced first by an appointed one. My father, Uifat Thali Peter Coleman, another major step forward to have a governor from our own people. He helped lead the forming of a constitution that started in 1960. The constitution took effect on July 1, 1967, yet another big step. In 1977, a long came another important step. The first constitutional elections were that year, electing my father as governor. By the choice of the people, the voters no longer by appointment of the federal government. In Washington, only handfuls of people truly understand most of this. In fact, I'm often asked questions. Sometimes I'm even asked, when will the two Samoas merge? I answer when Canada merges with the United States. We are called American Samoa for a reason. Much like the US and Canada, we share a lot of customs and language with our nearest neighbor, independent Samoa. But they are and will remain a friend and neighbor, not the same country. We are very proud of our ties to the United States. That said, we have one big difference. Unlike other US territories who are US citizens, American Samoans are US nationals. Neither citizens nor nationals of US territories vote in federal elections when residing in their territories, and they pay their taxes locally, not federally. On the flip side, we do participate in most federal funding programs such as Medicaid. These differences are designed in large part to protect our land and our culture by our choice and by agreement with the federal government. Any fundamental changes to our Constitution must be approved by both houses of Congress. For instance, there is a court case in which it appears we defeated, but that would have compelled United States citizenship on our people. Now, US citizenship can be a wonderful thing, but it absolutely must be a matter of self-determination for American Samoa. Our people have to make that decision for themselves. So far, the US courts have agreed to this principle in several major rulings. Because of this, we look forward to a future that maintains Fasamoa and that's part of the purpose of our Constitution. Enjoy your day learning about our Constitution. Soy Fua, Ma'iamanwea.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Rep. Tupola hosts  Congresswoman Aumua Amata Coleman Radewagen
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Content All right, welcome to bringing it back to the people. I'm Andrea Tufola, representative for District 43, the State House of Representatives, and I'm here with Amara Marta, who is also a Congresswoman from American Samoa, just recently elected, and we're going to talk about some of the things that she's been going through as a Congresswoman and see how some of that ties into what we're doing here in Hawaii, some of the things that we have in common is that we're both newly elected Samoa and women. And so I want this Congresswoman to basically explain to us a little bit about her background and how she got into the Congress. So the things that happened was that the prison held your seat prior to you after 26 years. That's right. And so how hard was it for you to win this election? It was very difficult. What we did was we conducted a very grassroots campaign, and what that meant was that we took the campaign and do every village, knocked on every door, climbed up and down mountains, knocked chaste and bitten by dogs. But another interesting aspect of it was that there were actually nine candidates running. So in addition to the 13-term income, there was also on ballot a two-term government plus six other candidates and then yourself. So it made particularly tough. But God blessed us on the next day. And fully intent to not disappoint the people. Of all the people who were running, how many of them are female? There were three females, including myself. And coming from a society where you come from, where it's kind of male dominated or you know, leadership, how did the people take that? And why do you think their presence was towards a female someone who would be represented this time around? Well, when I talked to my father about this, and a year ago, about wanting to run for public office, he looked at me and he said, well, it's going to be tough. It's going to take a very long time, probably 20 years. And as it turns out, that is how long it took for me to get in. See, I first started running in 1994. Really, I've run every two years for Congress since then. After 10 tries, I was ready to hang it up. But my supporters were just warming up. And so we decided to give it another go around. And on the level to try, we were victorious. Wow. Wow. That kind of surprised me because I didn't know that that had happened. Trying 11 times, I think here on how many people tried two, three times, and then they stopped. You know, they think maybe it's not their time for me. It was the very first time I had ever run. But my predecessor had held the seat for eight years. And in Hawaii, once you get in one election, it's so hard to lose your seat because of name recognition, because of just everyone kind of wanting the same person, the same status quo, whatever is being offered. And in Samoa, they must have really wanted a change. Because 26 years of having the same person. So what is going on in American Samoa that you think kind of generated that desire for a change? Well, I do think that the young people are waking up. Part of it is also the internet. And right now we are laying the fiber optic cable in the outer islands of Ophor, Seman, Tauro. And that means the communications will really explode. It was also the use of social media. Many, many Samoans like Facebook and all of this. We don't have access to the kind of campaign tools that are available up here. As you know, we have one weekly newspaper, in other words, one daily. And then one that comes out three times a week, and it's online. The one TV station is owned by the government. So you cannot ever use it for campaign campaigns. And then there's radio, which is fairly expensive. But what we did was we combined some state-side tactics along with cultural resources. And that's how we went ahead. But amazing, congratulations. I think for me, I had the same experience as her where you just have to get really grassroots when you're trying to run for office. If you really want to leverage the people, you have to go out there and be with the people and talk to the people. And I'm glad that now they have some social media. But regardless of social media, the face-to-face contact is really important. Because the people really know that you care about them. And so what is one of the things that you've pushed for since you've been elected? Well, we need better help in the area of health, education, and then jobs. We have quite a few unemployed people. And that's the result of our can-wee chicken of the sea closing up shop in 2009, the day after a killer tsunami hit us. So all in one fell swoop. Three thousand people were out of work. So jobs are extremely important right now. Our basic needs are needs that are taken for granted here in Hawaii, as well as the rest of the states. These are things that people have been getting up here for a long time. We're still struggling to improve our infrastructure, try to improve the disparity between American Samoan students in education. These are the ones in the states. So that is what we have been working very hard on. As far as my legislative agenda, these are just six little things that are based on what I talk to at the grassroots level. People said that this was important to them. And so we have already started to introduce legislation to that effect. It's been really, really exciting. I do not vote on House 4. But that's not really important because I remember the House Republican conference, which as you know is a formal assembly of Republican members. And all of the major pieces of legislation that are going to reach the House 4, get ironed out and discussed in the House Republican conference. We were just warming up. Good, good, I'm glad. Glad to hear that. In American Samoan, you guys also have a community college as you spoke about education. So how is the American Samoan community college going? And how are you looking to improve it for the people? Yes, absolutely. We lost our upward-bound program and little things like that help our youngsters, especially those who are, they could be the first person going to college in that particular family. So we have a four-year college in terms of you can get a bachelor's degree in education, but it's a two-year college for all other courses. And one of your things is also that you grew up here in Hawaii. Am I right? Did you go to high school here? I did grow up here, but I went to high school here at Sacred Hearts and I'm a kid. And with a special arrangement, I was able to board at Sacred Hearts Company one and then dance with drive me to come here. For all of you just tuning in, this is Congresswoman Almata Ray Lagam. And she's just recently elected to Congress. But what I'm mentioning here is that for many of the Samoans, you can correct me if I'm wrong. Coming to high school here in Hawaii is an opportunity that many of them take. And so she was able to attend Sacred Hearts. That's right. And so she does have some Hawaii connections. So coming here to Hawaii since you did your high school years here, how do you see it different or the same as what you have to do in American Samoan? It was quite a incarceration process for me. And I missed back home. I never thought that I would really go much beyond education in the village here. But my parents had some other things in mind. And they wanted me to broaden my horizons. So the first step was to come here at Sacred Hearts again. Very blessed. I grew up with the Hallock family and they lived next to us in Hawaii. And they went to Punehul. And I always thought that it was different because their parents still worked in Samoa. And they were still running the tune of business and everything. And their kids were just coming here for high school. And as soon as they finished, they went back to Samoa. But I see it as an opportunity, as you said, to broaden the horizon for the young people. And one of the things that she also did was that she appealed to the young people in this past election where she was successful. So what is the voter percentage out in Samoa? A lot of people get out in vote. Not so many. It's actually fairly high. In the last election, I would say the turnout was 85%. Certainly a lot more than in the United States. That's very high. And I don't know if you know the specific breakdown. But how many young people came out in vote? Were you guys able to do this spread of ages? Or is it mostly older folks that are voting? Quite a few of them were young people. Many of them voted for the first time. So part of our grassroots effort was we had to go reach out to them. There are young tongue-ends. When you were born in American Samoa, you were US national, whether you're Samoa or not. And we would go out into the villages and befriend them and bring them in to get them registered and so forth and so on. And it just kind of took off. I think the young people in American Samoa are looking for hope. They are looking for a better future and perhaps their parents are having. Yeah, yeah. It's very exciting because here in Hawaii we are struggling trying to get people to get out in vote. And I'm not sure if it's the same as Samoa, but here I think that we really had a lack of leadership. Now when I say that, I don't mean that we don't have leaders. We have leaders all over the place, but people can really inspire people and let them know that something will actually happen. When you vote, something might happen. I might listen to you and I think that one of the pieces of legislation you just put forward might give people that hope. Can you explain to us about your bill, about banking, that might help the people in Samoa? Well, it is a... ...checks that come in from off-violent or held by the bank for 21 days. And a lot of times people are trying to make the finances fit. That is a real hardship. So I hope to get that all done in the past, send it in. And that would be President Saundering to roll before too long. And we feel it as though our chances are quite good. It's exciting because even though it sounds like maybe it's something small, it's something that's going to affect every person in Samoa. That's right. And that's the kind of legislation that we need to pass is the ones that are going to help people in their everyday struggles. Not in the struggles that are in five or ten years, but the struggles we have every day. One of the things she brought up is that it's almost like fixing a pothole. For the people in Hawaii, some of the stuff that I'm doing doesn't take legislation to fix traffic or to help them with the commute home. And this is what people are looking for. The looking for leaders that are going to help them get through their everyday struggles and know that their elected officials are listening to them. And that's something very important that both she and I agree on is that the people's voices need to be heard and that's why we're grassroots. That's why we're talking to the people because we wanted to hear what they had to say about how we could make our communities better. So, Congresswoman, is there anything else you'd like to share with us as far as your new journey in the US, Congress? How has it felt? Oh, it is great. And I look forward to continuing to work with you. And I'm just very, very excited and I see a great right future ahead for you. And I'm all the best. Thank you. Thank you so much for tuning in. Bringing it back to the people for all you saw Moons out there for the title of the Lava will be back and hopefully she and I will do more things together. Other huh?
