partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Music Afidee. All right, the Lofa Lava. So happy to see you here. So happy to see our special guest here. This is quite an opportunity for us here at the University of Guam to hear from someone who's very special. There's a lot of intersections in her life with the life, not only of the University of Guam, the only member of Congress ever who is a graduate of the University of Guam. Right? So. And they're very happy to know that. And of course, in the course of that, her life is intersected with a number of people over the years here at the University of Guam, including the Yamashita family and others and Sanchez. And of course, actually friends for a long time with Senator Mary Torres. So this is an amazing experience. So, you know, I've known her since I was elected in back in the early 90s to serve in Washington, DC. Of course, she was from a different political party. But, you know, we were islanders. And so that always kind of makes sure that you kind of work together. And she is the number one, the most senior member of the Republican National Committee. So, you know, I want to lay that out because I don't ever want to be accused that I only invite Democrats to come to this. I come to the stage, you know. And I also want to acknowledge that Speaker Cruz kind of jerrymandered the session early today so that they could come here. And so we're very happy for that. And she's had, you know, in addition to being the third member of the House of Representatives as Congressional delegate from America and Samoa being preceded by the late, any Phaleo Maveenga and Fofo Sonia. She's also had many years of experience here, lived in the Marshall Islands when her father was, the Honorable Peter Coleman was district administrator, distad. I don't know how many people remember that term distad. I know there's a couple of people out there who remember that that's a really old arcade colonial term, I want to say, distad, district administrator. And of course also served as Deputy High Commissioner of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands in Saipan. And so, you know, she had the opportunity to live both in the Marshall Islands and in Saipan. And of course, here on Guam as well as she came to school here. So, you know, she's had, I was just remarking how lucky we were because I was watching a signing ceremony on the Marine Monuments the other day on CNN. And, you know, of course, people were criticizing what President Trump was doing and some were applauding what he was doing. But standing right behind him was, you know, Congresswoman Radowagin. So, she's a force inside the National Republican Party has been, if you've watched National Politics over the years, if you've watched National Conventions, she's there. She's always played some kind of a very strong participatory role. And I think she really takes that role seriously in terms of her relationship to the broader Pacific Island community. And so, it's with great pleasure and honor that I introduce to you the Honorable Amata Radowagin. Thank you very much, Dr. Underwood. It's indeed a blessing and a privilege to be here today. And I'm just delighted. This is my second home. I am from American Samoa. And we do have this little custom that whenever there are two or more Samoans in the audience that we say a couple of words in the native language. So, it won't take too long if you will allow me. I told her, you know, I was out among the two. Now, if you were to think of Samoa, but you know, the people, the power, the sun, they are more than enough to pay the lot to them and then they are more than enough. Everybody calls me Amata or Amua Amata. And I am from American Samoa. Samoans are very ethnocentric. In fact, they believe that Samoa is a garden of Eden because God puts Samoans there directly. As evidence, they cite the fact that the word Samoa means holy center or sacred soul, sacred heart. And they are the only islands in Polynesia that have no folklore about canoes coming from somewhere else. To give you an example of Samoa and ethnocentricity, I want to tell you about a high chief during World War II. As a U.S. territory, American Samoa was being used as a staging area and resupply area in the rear of the front lines where the battles were going on. But in order to use the land for military purposes, the military had to get permission from the chiefs because that was part of the deal that was struck in the deed of session. All was going well in negotiations, but then the military came upon an old chief who absolutely refused to make his land available at any price. They tried and tried to negotiate, but he wouldn't budge. When the report was read by the high command in Honolulu Sinkpack, who was the top military commander for the entire Pacific War, he ordered his negotiators to invite the chief for a visit to Hawaii, where Sinkpack would negotiate himself. The old chief came up and was ushered into Sinkpack's office, which had a huge map of the region on his wall stretching from end to end. Getting up from his chair and going to the map, the Sinkpack gestured to the chief with his arm, saying, do you see that huge landmass on the left side of the map? And the chief nodded his head, yes. That is China, moving to the other side, Sinkpack continued. And do you see that large landmass on the right? Again, the chief nodded. And do you see that tiny little dot in the middle way down below the equator? That is Samoa. The old chief got up from his chair slowly, walked over to the map, put on his glasses, bent down and peered at the little dot. Then he stood up straight again, turned to the Sinkpack and said, who made this map? So when Dr. Underwood invited me to give his lecture, I was more than happy to do it because it would give me chance to come back to Guam, which I consider home, second home. Later he asked if I had a title of my lecture. I said, yes, my road to Congress runs through Guam. I learned a lot of lessons on the way. One of the first was that I would be in the public eye because my father was prominent from his days as Attorney General of American Samoa back in 1955. And then for the next 40 years, dad would be the this dad or chief administrator of one island or another. So I was never very far from the spotlight. The second thing I learned was the importance of education that my parents would always stress to me. I grew up in American Samoa, but when my father left the governorship to become the chief executive or administrator of the Marshall Islands, my parents thought it best to send me to Honlulu to school where we had family. Next four years, I attended Sacred Hearts Academy and lived in a convent where my dad's sister was a semi-coistered nun. The Marshall Islands was my first introduction to Micronesia and the next stop on my road to Guam. And as I was finishing up high school, my parents were asked to come to Sipan where dad became the district administrator of the Northern Mariana Islands. I first set foot on Guam while en route to Sipan. Once again, there being no college at all in American Samoa and no university of Guam. I believe it was still College of Guam. I graduated from Sacred Hearts in Honlulu. My parents encouraged me to go to college in the States. Work hard, Amata. Work hard. God helps those who help themselves. I remember all these stories that dad would tell me. He had a lot of little stories. I think that we children, all 13 of us, remember every single story just because we used to joke with each other that our dad actually spoke in parables. So the story is that a man was sitting on his front porch when it started to rain. The rain came down harder and harder and the man realized it was a flood. So the flood waters were rising and when the water started to spill over the porch, a man and a robot came by and the man and the robot says, do you need any help? Come with us. But the man said, nope, the Lord will take care of me. Few hours later, that man was standing on a chair on his front porch and a motorboat comes by. And the man yells inside, do you need any help? Come with us. But the man smiled and says, nope, the Lord will take care of me. A few hours later, the man is now on his roof and a helicopter comes by and the pilot yells down at him. Do you need any help? It's getting late. But the man just said, nope, the Lord will take care of me. A few hours later, the flood got to be too much for the man and he drowned. And when he got to heaven, he asked the Lord, Lord, why didn't you take care of me? I always trusted in you that you would always take care of me. The Lord said, well, I sent you a robot and a motorboat. I even sent you a helicopter. What else did you want? After that, I said, buddy, you're on your own. But so getting back to where to go to college, I could have gone to the University of Hawaii, but mom and dad wanted me to broaden my horizons. And one of the reasons I was attracted to Los Angeles was that, like Ireland, we also had relatives there. But at least they weren't in a convent. Just as I had gone home to the Marshall Islands every summer for years from school in Honolulu. While in college in Los Angeles, I also came home every summer to Sipan. So I actually spent three years in college in Los Angeles and then Loyola decided to merge with Marymount. And even though I'd been in LA for quite a while getting adjusted, it just seemed like I needed to go home, home to the islands. So the College of Guam was now the University of Guam. I enrolled. Dad and mom talked to the President of UOG, Dr. Yamashita and his lovely wife who were happy to give me a room in their beautiful home. And I cannot thank the Yamashita's enough for their kindness and understanding. And I'm just so privileged that Mrs. Yamashita and the younger daughter Duchess, I knew them as Duchess in Princess. I know they have grown up names. I think it's Velma. But I can't thank them enough. Many times I get out of my last class and I go to their home way past dinner time. And even though the family might have already gone to bed, Mrs. Yamashita always left dinner in the oven for me and I especially loved her mistake. So Mrs. Yamashita, thank you from the bottom of my heart. I wouldn't be where I am today without the help of this kind family. And when I talked to Dr. Underwood recently, he said that Mrs. Yamashita was still with us. And now we're so blessed to have her actually right in this room with us today. So thank you from the bottom of my heart, Mrs. Yamashita. So although I did spend three years at Loyola Marymount, it was really my one year that I spent here that I truly enjoyed and cared about. And I was sorry to leave at the time. Yam was on the verge of a new chapter in its history. A year later, I believe, they elected their own governor and member of Congress. The previous summer when I was home on CYPAN, I met a young man who was part of a White House National Security Task Force doing a survey of the economic development of my Kronizha. So when he came to CYPAN, we'd get together and talk and drink coffee. I believe it was 1970 when Antonio Wampat came to Congress. Although I was three credits short, I could not resist the urge to take a job I'd been offered in Washington, DC. The young man who later became my husband also would always come to Guam. And around that same time, American Samoa elected its own delegate at large and I worked for him. Paramount Chief Aou Fumonou. One thing I did do was to join the Guam Society of America in DC. So my oldest friends came from Guam. There was no American Samoa Society until much later. But Guam Society was already organized. So I've actively participated over the years. I then went on to work for the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare. And indeed, American Samoa decided to elect its own governor around that time. And then another opportunity came up to come back to Guam in CYPAN. So I found a reason to come back to Guam. And it wasn't a shock to see how much progress Guam had made. Now, when I first ran for Congress in 1984, I finished with almost 30% of the vote. Dad's health had begun to fade. And I told him I really wanted to go for Congress. Well, he encouraged me to try again, but he said, you know, Amata, American Samoa is at least 20 years away from electing a woman to Congress. You need to know that. I really know it now because it took me 22 years to get into Congress. So dad, you were right on. And so down there, I was also active in the village, the local community, and the church, things, including the women's hospital, auxiliary, and mammography. We didn't have a mammogram machine. So I decided to raise funds off Island and began to speak publicly about the need for one. I ran again in 1996 and came up short. In 1998, I didn't get on the ballot because my supporters wanted to also launch a right-in campaign. Something that never had been done in American Samoa. The Election Commissioner refused to count my ballots and asked each polling station to destroy all my ballots. Well, in halfway through the counting process, after they thrown away three quarters of them, I'm sure, he reversed himself and said he would count my votes. Well, I ended up with 700 votes, you know. And because so many others had been destroyed. And in 2000, my supporters came back again and asked me to run again. To make a long story short, I had run unsuccessfully ten times and won on my 11th try. So when I came to Washington in 2015, when I mentioned that I had run 11 times, people gasped in disbelief. Some even actually fainted, you know. But the lesson I learned is never to give up perseverance. I ran all those times because I felt the voters deserved a choice. I didn't necessarily disagree with the incumbent, but he had a different approach. And in 2014, the voters spoke. And that year, there were actually nine candidates running for Congress. And I said to myself, there is no way I'm going to get past any. Then Governor Tonyola, a two-term governor who had just finished his second term. And then there was a military veteran who had his own built-in base. Plus, the other five candidates, including myself. But you know, perseverance is something I also learned in Guam. Because I was still short of three credits and was working in Washington for the Secretary of HEW. I told Mrs. Rosa Carter, she's another person I owe a great debt of gratitude to, that it would be impossible for me to physically return to take that one course in Guam. She told me, Amata, if you can get an accredited college in Washington that we can approve, then yes. You can get those three credits transferred to Guam. So, instead of being in the class of 70, which really I was supposed to be, I graduated with the class of 1975, which is actually a good thing because now people think I'm much younger than I really am. But thanks to Rosa Carter, I got my degree. Every weekend I would fly home to Sipan in those days on Air Mike, student airfare, $8 one day to go on the 737. So, when I first came to Congress, my colleagues knew very little about Americans a lot more. And I was part of the House Republican Conference. And so, because it's very rare to have a Republican delegate, they're always all Democrats, you know. And so, naturally there were a lot of questions after they found out I ran 11 times. They wanted to know about the pace of life in Americans, some more. And would I have the ability to adjust all these questions, you know. And Republican delegate, as I said, was kind of a rare bird. But it reminded me of that story of the American and the Pacific Island fishermen. And an American investment banker was at the pier of a small Pacific Island village when a small boat with just one fisherman docked. Inside the small boat were several large yellow fin tuna. The American complimented the Islander on the quality of his fish and asked how long it took to catch them. The Islander replied, only a little while. The American then asked, why didn't you stay out longer and catch more fish? The Islander said, with this, I have more than enough to support my family's needs. The American then asked, but what do you do with the rest of your time? The Islander said, well, I sleep late, fish a little, play with my children, take a nap with my wife. And in the evening I stroll into the village and where I drink beer and play my ukulele with my friends. I have a full and busy life. As innocuous as the title non-voting delegate sounds. I've already said it. They have all the rights. Except that one, the final passage. But they can introduce legislation. They can offer amendments and substitutes. They have full access to the House floor. They can speak on the floor, participate in debate, manage bills, sit on committees and fully vote in those committees. It goes on and on. They can chair subcommittees and full committees. Finally, in American Samoa, we have a saying, on all of the pool or the Tautua, meaning the road to leadership is paved with service. And it may have been in the old days applied to people in their villages. And today, my road to service went through Guam. My people in American Samoa were willing to agree that these things were not only in American Samoa, but Guam as well. So ifua, thank you. Thank you. We'd like to open the floor for some questions. Yes. Yes. We're still wrestling with this issue. I think it's a little bit of a problem. I think it's a little bit of a problem. I think it's a little bit of a problem. There's a U.S. National who was born and raised and is living in American Samoa. Many of them come up to the states. And what happens for them is that they begin to participate in their communities. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Western Caucus Weekly Address - Week of October 28, 2017 | Rep. Aumua Amata Radewagen
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: I'm pleased to join you today with an update for the Western Caucus. I'm proud to represent American Samoa, a beautiful group of seven islands in the Pacific Ocean. We may not be the first place you think of in the Western Caucus. I joined this caucus not just because we are thousands of miles to the west of most of the country, but because of shared interests and priorities. For instance, we have two rainy seasons, so we aren't as likely to see a furious wildfire like those causing so much damage this year in the Western U.S. Instead, our highly trained teams of expert firefighters went in during those efforts. When the firebell rings, that's what firefighters do. They respond and wherever they're from, we're proud of them all. Like other parts of the West, we in American Samoa have beautiful places and coastlines, including National Park and Monument areas that cover both sea and land. Very proud of the work the Western Caucus has put into these issues and the leadership of so many of my colleagues. In each of our districts, our monument area might look a little different from another place, but there are important underlying issues that are the same. For instance, is there good local input from the people who know the area best? We're working together in Congress to ensure state, local and territorial input for monument decisions. That's just common sense. Protecting beautiful places doesn't have to cause harm to nearby small businesses. That's why a bureaucracy in Washington, D.C. shouldn't be the only one with a voice. In American Samoa, decisions in Washington about a marine monument placed our traditional fishing grounds and waters off limits, despite generations of use. Fishing is part of our heritage and Fassamoa, our special way of life. We're working together so that Congress must be consulted on future marine monument decisions so the people living there are truly represented, just as the country's founders intended. That's just a small part of what the Western Caucus is all about, and that's why we work together in Congress to keep these beautiful places, mountains, deserts and islands. Not only beautiful, but also free, prosperous, and respectful of our heritage. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Congresswoman Aumua Amata
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Thank you, Mr. Radarwagon, you're recognized. Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I welcome the panel. Thank you for your appearance today. Ms. Bradley, before VA compiled the documents to satisfy this committee's request, have you or anyone else at VA ever compiled all of these settlement agreements into one place for a nationwide review so you could see the overall cost of taxpayers? I have not. Ms. Bradley, has any thought been given to doing what it is I asked about? In other words, you say nothing's been compiled but has any thought been given to such a possibility? Well, I don't want the committee to believe that nothing's been compiled. You asked me if my office, I'm in the Office of General Council, we didn't compile that data. We don't track the total number of payouts. I think that it's fair to say that the administrations are very attentive and track that information as they should because, again, these are business decisions and the money comes out of their operating budget. I would say what I track as the general council is, can we show our veterans, can we show the American people, can we show this committee that when we uncover wrongdoing, whether it's racial discrimination, or whether it's whistleblower retaliation, or something along those lines, can we show the American people that we will hold those wrongdoers accountable? That is what I've been really focused on doing in my office, focused on doing it in our training, focused on doing it with respect to the standup of the office in my shop called the Office of Accountability Review, ensuring that we have put really top-notch investigators on the Office of Accountability Review, so they can provide to us competent investigations with sound evidence so that when we take these actions, we won't have them overturned. Those are some of the things that my office and that I personally have been focused on. And speaking as my previous job as a medical center director, that was a fundamental piece of what I looked at regularly with the rest of the leadership team, was, for example, the number of EEO complaints that we have, the number of labor grievances, those sort of human resource indicators that would give us a sense of the health of the organization. And from a VBA perspective, we do the same thing at the district. Obviously, we're probably a fraction of the size of VHA, so we can look even closer at those agreements from a enterprise level. So at each of our districts, as well as in our office, a resolution management within VBA, we do that same thing. Mr. Bachman, what level of transparency do you have into whether employees who retaliate against whistleblowers are properly disciplined? As I said, our first mission, our primary responsibility at OSC is to make sure we're helping to protect whistleblowers. And through that, we have been using settlement agreements with the VA to make sure that they're able to get back on their job, continue serving veterans. And that's really needed to be our primary responsibility. At the same time, however, we have really been working to approve actions on the disciplinary front to help the VA improve accountability there. And to that end, we've got several ongoing disciplinary action investigations, I've mentioned. But I think an important one to point out is that over the last few years, the VA is disciplined over 40 VA employees who were implicated in wrongdoing that was brought to light by VA whistleblowers who would come to OSC to make their whistleblower discloser there. And I think that's an important point because it shows the role that whistleblowers, as well as OSC, can take in helping the VA to improve their accountability. Two of those 40 folks that the VA has disciplined, those involved removals of high level officials at the Fort Collins, Colorado facility, which was struggling with the wait time manipulation problem there. So I think there has been an ability to take some accountability, not always through the strict litigation sense, but through other coordination between OSC and VA. Thank you, Mr. Chairman, I yield back. Thank you very much, Mr. Radowaggin.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Watch Rep. Linda Snchez speak at the 2016 Democratic National Convention
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: We are here at this historic Democratic Convention to nominate Hillary Clinton, the next president, and Tim Cain, the next vice president of the United States. I want to share a little bit of my story because it's an American story. It's the story of millions of Latinos and Latinas across this country. I'm the daughter of immigrant parents from Mexico. They came to this country and worked hard every day to provide for me and my brothers and sisters. My father Ignacio was an industrial mechanic and my mother Maria became an elementary school teacher after raising a family. They owned their own home. They sent all seven of their children to college. My mother and father saved and sacrificed to achieve the American dream for our family. They weren't given their success. They earned it. Donald Trump believes that Mexican immigrants are murders and rapists. But what about my parents, Donald? Let me tell you what my parents are. They are the only parents in our nation's 265-year history to send not one but two daughters to the United States Congress. Like my parents, Hillary Clinton believes the United States is a country where people of all backgrounds can make a home and a better life. But that America isn't possible if we allow Donald Trump and his Republican Party to build a wall that divides us. I stand here tonight as the chair of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and a proud Congresswoman from California, but most importantly, I'm here as a mom. We all want what's best for our kids. We want our children to grow up to be healthy, successful and kindhearted. Our job is to nurture them and be good role models for them to follow as they grow. Now I'll be the first to tell you that being a parent is hard, but Donald Trump is making it a whole lot harder. He has taken the low road time and time again. He's been vulgar and he's been intolerant or as we say in Spanish, unseem that whensa. He peddles fear and insecurity to divide the people of this great country. Tell me what kind of example would we set for our children by allowing a bully to sit in the overall office? We know that our children aren't born with hate or racism in their hearts. They learn it from watching the world around them and following the example of the adults in their life. Too many of our children are watching and learning the wrong lessons from Donald Trump. We've seen it in Indiana basketball game where a group of white students started chanting build that wall to taunt players from a predominantly Hispanic high school. This is the behavior that Donald Trump inspires in our youth. A Trump presidency would be a signal to our children that we condone this kind of behavior. Well that is a message I refuse to accept. Who we vote for says a lot about our values. There are few moments in history that have an impact on the trajectory of the world. I believe that this election is one of those moments. Our children are watching us. Their future depends on the outcome of this race. Do we want a responsible leader or allowed mouthful? Do we want a president who respects women or who calls them names and devalues them? Do we want a president who appreciates the contributions immigrants make to our country or someone who vilifies them? Hillary Clinton is the only choice for president. She is a president we can be proud of. And Donald, let me just say this. America is great. It is the country that gave my family the opportunity for a better life just like all immigrants who came before them. It is because of our diversity that we are the envy of the world. Hillary simply knows how to do it and he knows what he needs. We have to respect and respect the elections in November. Like I said in the video, Hillary Clinton is badass and ready to lead. Let's win in November.

Well, there are two resolutions last year in Congress. The House did just that. They voted against the clean power plan. I mean, if that were to come up, how would you vote? Don't know yet. I don't see what the plan would be. If it did not include those elements of making sure communities are made whole, making sure that there's a national policy on power, and making sure that we are not just closing plans for the sake of politics versus then what's going on in the rest of the world, then I would vote for it. What about the president's plan for a Grand Canyon area monument? Controversial could come up for a vote. I would vote for that. I vote for Ray Sonoleta in of support. Okay. So for those who say that it's too much, it takes too many jobs, and it takes too much opportunity away from not the Grand Canyon itself, but the Grand Canyon area up there, you say. I don't know what jobs people are saying that it's going to take away. The battle industry is protected, the only thing that does not allow in that area is mining. And hunters are protected, and in fact it protects a watershed and it protects jobs because of tourism in that area. You know that you're going to get a very vociferous argument on the other side and it's going to come very often from the president on down now. How effective can Democrats be on Capitol Hill getting things done? Well I think that people are rushing ahead of themselves in this whole thought process that Democrats are going to be irrelevant. Within the Republican caucus, there's already people talking about things that they don't like within the president's plans. I see a caucus at one time or another is going to fracture along some lines and some issues. Then that allows the opening for Democrats to negotiate. I was going to say we talk about the Affordable Care Act a lot because it looks like it's headed for a fall. Although, again, President-elect Trump says he's not going to do anything without a replacement plan. Your fellow representative-elect Andy Bigg says, well, not a replacement. It's got to be an alternative. You can't just get rid of it. How do you plan to fight for the provisions in the Affordable Care Act? Well the provisions that are in there are some of the cost drivers that are affecting the plan. And so what I said in my campaign is I want to take a look at those cost drivers to see if they're needed, they're relevant, and to improve the plan, not to do away with the plan. And when you talk, all of a sudden, it's easy to say things on the campaign trail about doing away with the Affordable Care Act. It's much harder when you're affecting families and the lives of our citizens. And that's what we're talking about now. Now reality is at the table. And reality says you need to find something to replace it, and it has to be something that allows those citizens and more citizens to be able to afford health insurance. Republicans say there is something out there. It's market driven in general for the most part, market driven. Could you live with something like that? I haven't seen a market driven- we're here because of market driven insurance. And the fact that we had an Affordable Care Act because it wasn't being taken care of. And whether it's, you take a family in poverty that's above the line for excess in the state of Arizona, Medicaid. And they don't have the resources for a savings plan, a medical savings plan. They don't care about a tax credit because the tax credit, they don't pay taxes because they're under a certain level. And a family of four making $40,000 a year, they can't afford this health insurance. Whether it's the Affordable Care Act or other concerns, you mentioned working with Republicans. There might be some opportunities there as perhaps Republican caucus fractures in ways that we can't even imagine right now. The campaign you were quoted as saying, we are at our best when we are united. The country does not feel united and Capitol Hill does not feel united. Washington doesn't. How do you get that unification to happen? Well, I don't think we are united right now as a country and politically. And how you get to do it is I'm part of a freshman class of Republicans and Democrats and we just came back from a Kennedy School government where we dealt with policy. And one of the things those that were at the school said was we are going to work together. We are going to meet on a regular basis. I joined a group called the New Dums. We work with Republicans, put our hand out and say, let's work together on these major issues affecting the citizens of Arizona and the United States. So you don't do it by taking jabs of people by just saying, you know, they are wrong. You do it by working together and creating public policy that's for the betterment, not political betterment, but the betterment of society. But I can hear Democrats and critics saying that's all fine and dandy, but it's one thing to say I'm going to work with Republicans. It's another to say I'm going to work with Republicans when they won't work with you. Well, it's impossible to work with somebody that refuses to work with you. And they have to show that they are willing to work. And if they're not willing to work, we still have to look at the policy that comes out. I don't know what Mr. Trump is going to put out as public policy. Nobody does. I know what I've heard. I have some very serious concerns about some of his nominations and so forth. What's the biggest concern of what he's done so far? Anything on foreign policy. I mean, I've never in my entire life seen a president of president elect start to get involved so much in foreign policy. You take a look at the statement he made on Twitter again today about the F-35, which is important to Arizona. And Lockheed Martin lost $4 billion at one point during the market today. I mean, that is just not the appropriate thing for somebody. It's not involved in our foreign policy yet, and not involved in our procurement system yet, defense yet. Do you think that there is a smoking gun that shows that Russian hackers tried to intervene in this election cycle? I'm not any intelligence committee and probably won't be as a freshman, but I can say this. If there is the hint of it and there is, then we should look into it. We should not allow this type of thing to go on answered. We have to make sure the integrity of our electoral system is kept intact and that no foreign powers are able to do what could have been done under the circumstances. The likely number two of the State Department, John Bolton, is saying that the Democrats, the Democrats, could be responsible for hacking into this election because of a false flag situation. In other words, you do the dirty stuff and then blame it on your opponents. You buy that? John Bolton said a lot of things over the last number of years. I don't buy it. And Mr. Bolton didn't offer any proof that this occurred. So until you offer proof, and that's why I think the bipartisan group has gotten together and said, let's take a good hard look at this together and make sure that we know what we're talking about. Up until now, whether it's myself or others out there, until you get the investigation done, none of us really know what we're talking about. How did your orientation go? When you first went back to DC and they were shuttling you around all over the place? Well, shuttling you around is true. That went great. I enjoy the look into the future of beginning congressman. I enjoy the debates that we had meeting other congressmen from both parties, making sure that we started to develop our offices and our staff and starting to get a foundation built to, in my case, represent Congressional District 1. And I've got a good Washington staff already on board and part of my district staff is on board. Has anything you didn't expect? Not really. I mean, I just think it's scale. Yes. And the awesome responsibility that you've taken on to make sure that when that scale has developed that way, that we do have a competent staff, that we do make sure that constituents see work is taken care of. And at the same time that we do our homework on public policy. Planning of scale, Congressional District 1, is huge. It is mammoth. You're five hours away by playing just from the district and then to cover the district, you're going to have to do a lot of travel. How are you going to represent all of these people from so far away? Well, tomorrow we start our trip through the Navajo Reservation and then on the way back, start doing some of the cities and towns in northern Arizona. And then the next day we go into the eastern part of the state for two days. And then the two days after that, we go down into the southern part of the district. And we will continue to make these rotations through. I told the citizens of Congressional District 1 that I was going to be at their meetings and I am going to be there. And last question I've been asking is if all of our Congress people, especially when they first get elected, has the gravity of all this sunk in? If it hasn't, you better not have taken the job. This is serious work. And you need to take it seriously. And the awesome, that awesome responsibility, you told people that you're going to represent them. They might disagree with you at times, but your job is to make sure you know the facts. And that is going to be something that's going to be a challenge on a continuing basis. All right. Well, again, congratulations. Good luck to you and thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it. Thanks, David. Appreciate it. And Tuesday on Arizona Horizon, we visit with Democratic Congressman Ruben Garnett. We're the guy ego of District 7 and Democratic Congresswoman Kirsten Sinema of Congressional District 9. That's tomorrow 530 and 10 here on Arizona Horizon. That's it for now. I'm Ted Simon. Thanks for joining us. You have a great evening. Thank you. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Rep. Andy Biggs: Rest in Peace Charlie Kirk, Loving Friend, Husband, and Father
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Today, we tragically lost a tremendous leader and a friend. We didn't lose him so much as he was taken from us. Charlie Kirk was an inspiration to an entire generation, and I believe that his legacy will grow. He will be remembered as someone who changed the course of this nation. He was the founder of one of the most influential political movements of our time. We live in an interesting time. We see political movements, President Trump, as fostered the Magga movie, perhaps the most powerful in the history of the country. But Charlie Kirk, let's just talk about what he did in Arizona, and then we'll talk about his most important contributions. He founded an organization, T.P. Turning Point, USA, and a whole affiliate of related turning point. And they're headquartered right there in Arizona, and he was just absolutely remarkable. So in Arizona, it was about a ground state, right? What did they do? In our state, turning point action together with other coalitions actually turned out more than 300,000 low propensity Republican voters, right? What's the difference? The difference was it made there, Donald Trump win Arizona. It helped Donald Trump win Arizona by the largest margin of any battleground state, 160,000 votes, a 5% five point victory there. So he fostered a movement, but he did it foster the movement because he was smart. He was erudite. He was passionate. He was generally calm. He took on all the cameras, and I'm afraid to talk with anyone about his message. So, while we consider this movement, we know that people in his generation and younger are actually moving to the right. And a lot of people say they're moving to the right because they've been disassociated by the left. They've been disillusioned by the left. And I think there's probably some of that to it, but they don't move to the right unless there's an invitation. And so he invited people to come. To share his love of freedom, family, faith, God, and country. So Charlie will be an historic figure. He really will be. And he will be one more, and along line of those who are good, whose life is snuffed out by those who are evil. But his memory will remain strong. And I would suggest that the most important role that Charlie filled was as a loving husband and a father, and about Christian who shared his faith unapologetically without fear, with tremendous courage, charisma, and compassion. My family invokes our thoughts and prayers on behalf of Erika and Erika Charlie's two young children. We pray that God covers them with peace and gives them the comfort of the Holy Ghost. I think I want to just close David with a couple of things. There is, we always say there's no place for political violence in this country, and there should not be. This assassination was meant to instill fear. It was an actual assassination, a political assassination. So what must we do? Well, we certainly speak peace and truth and comfort, but we respond with courage because the message Charlie brought was there is a good way this country has much to offer everyone. So we will double down. We will reinvigorate and restart our engine and those who want to destroy this country, whether it be because they want to destroy our faith in God, whether they want to destroy our freedom, whether they want to destroy our education, David, you mentioned then. We will persevere because there is much to be learned from this young man. And so I say with my family, God bless you and your family, Charlie. God bless the entire TPUSA team who are in mourning grieving. And God bless the message of freedom that America stands for. David, thank you. Thank you for letting me take a moment. I'll see you back.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: 'We've Been Making A Lot Of Progress': Juan Ciscomani Celebrates Republican Achievements
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Hello everyone, thank you for being here. I want to thank Speaker McCarthy and the whole leadership of the conference for these amazing seven months as I started my journey in Congress every time people asked me, you know, how's it going? It's going. It's fast and we've been making a lot of progress and I'm very happy about that. Also, Ken say that I'm not happy about going home today. It's always good news and for me, going home keeps me informed, keeps me connected, and it keeps me married as well. So that's always a good thing to do. But I'm proud of the work that we've done, I'm proud of the work that we've delivered as a conference. We all ran on different promises and in my case was one of economic opportunity, the freedom to pursue the American dream and the way that we are safe and we continue to keep our commitment to keep our community safe. And that is what I want to talk to you just a little bit about today. My border is a border district, as you know in South Eastern Arizona, and border security is a big piece of our daily lives. And the relationship with Mexico specifically is a big piece of our daily lives. I was born in Mexico and I immigrated to the United States when I was 11 years old. Became a United States citizen in 2006 and was elected to Congress in 2022. This is the land of opportunity, no question about it. Don't know where else in the world could we have this kind of story and opportunity. With it comes the rule of law though. With it comes responsibility to protect our borders from those trying to do harm to us. And there's a lot of cartel activity that you know about. And they've been dominating the traffic on the border, the legal traffic for a long time that is hurting the positive, by cultural and also trade relationship that we've had with Mexico for so long. Who is our ally and our friend. These cartels and this illegal activity have taken over the trafficking of both drugs and women and children and overall people across this and that must be stopped. And that's exactly one of the pillars of my campaign when I ran for office. And of course that was a pillar of what we had to do when we set out the plan to our commitment to America. So with that I want to just say that we are keeping our commitment to America by delivering on the safe nation and with that came HR 2. This was a build that it seems now that it was passed a long time ago and may seem that way because of all that we've done in between. But this is an important piece of legislation that highlighted the priorities that we have both to secure the border and add resources to that and also reform loops and gaps within the asylum system that has been so heavily abused. Also, while protecting on the company of children. That was a big point for me and that was something that I have to give a lot of credit to the leadership for giving me a seat at the table as a freshman as someone that wasn't in any of the committees that were moving these bills forward but I still had a real seat at the table. I'm being able to give our thoughts and opinions both of my personal experience and also my professional experience working on the border. So I am proud of the bill that we put forward. Also I've been assigned to the task force on the cartel task force. This is we've been meeting for a couple of weeks now getting expert advice and we're going to be setting out a plan as we look deeper into the cartel activities and how legislation from Congress can help tackle that problem as well. The efforts around fentanyl can be overstated. We've set this before that every border has become a border state due to the fentanyl crisis. My home county of Pima County now is the home for the leading cost of death among young people being fentanyl overdose deaths. That is tragic. That has surpassed now car accidents and unfortunately there hasn't been a positive curve on that yet because of this administration's failure to tackle the real problem, both secure the border and tackle the problem regarding the cartels. Also providing strong support to our military might district this home to over 70,000 veterans. That's a 9th largest veteran population in the country in terms of congressional districts. I'm proud to represent two military bases and DM Air Force base in forward Chuka. Like I said, 70,000 veterans living in our community that we've been able to advocate for as a member of the veteran affairs committee as well. And then as the leader and others have mentioned today passing the military construction and veteran affairs package. Very proud of this one. Proud of what we've been able to do and hold the line and the funding for our veterans but also up it even more and make sure that they have all the needs that they need. Also correcting the record on whatever lies were said about our efforts or our intent to cut anything on veterans. That's absolutely not the case and we prove that by making this the first appropriations bill. And speaking of appropriations, I am proud to be appointed to the appropriations committee and serve on that this entire time as the only freshman in this class to be able to do that. The only member in the Arizona delegation and I want to thank the leadership speaker McArthur and and and and leaders Gilles and Tom and just everyone Stephanie everyone because they've given me that opportunity to be on there and represent and carry the voice of our freshman class in the appropriations process. As I said, we're heading all back home today. Proud of the work that we've done by knowing that there's a lot of work to be done and the time at home it's a work period where we get to go and talk to people and listen even more. And you know the only way you can actually be happy to go back to 115 degree weather is to be leaving 100 degree human weather here in DC. So with that, thank you so much for your time and I would like to turn it over to my friend representative Mary Ned Miller and Beeks.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: 'The Eyes Of The World Are On Us': Ciscomani Nominates McCarthy For Speaker
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: For what purpose does the gentleman from Arizona rise? Madam Clerk, our rights nominate Kevin McCarthy is speaker of the House. The gentleman is recognized. Thank you Madam Clerk. The American Dream is a dream. The American Dream is a dream worth fighting for. And I know in my hearts of hearts that Kevin McCarthy is the man to lead us as we work to fulfill that dream for everyone. And every state and every district. Everyone in this chamber understands the need to serve our constituents. It's who elected us and our responsibility. Kevin understands this as well as anyone. He has dedicated his life to spreading opportunity for all through the private sector and the public sector. This place is a special place for me. My first time on the hill was back when I was in the end of 2003. My mom visited and I remember walking around the halls of Congress as if I owned a place. Just a few days ago, I got to walk my mom around one more time, this special place. But now, as a member elect of the United States House of Representatives. The American Dream is alive. I believe it. I've gone to know Kevin McCarthy well. He's a curator of Republican majority in the United States House and laid out a plan to deliver for the American people. There's one thing that I know about Kevin McCarthy. He cares about the American people. He cares about our country. And is here not to be somebody but to do something. And that has been laid out in his commitment to America. To fight for an economy that is strong, a nation that is safe, a future that is built on freedom, and a government that is accountable. This, I can strongly get behind. This country gave me and my family an opportunity, an opportunity to achieve the American Dream. Friends, I was born in Mexico. The best way that I can tell you who I am is through a short conversation I had with my dad. When I told him, I was going to run for office. This conversation, of course, in Spanish. My dad asked me, Juan, where else could we have our story? We come to this country. We immerse in the culture. We learn English. We go through the long journey and become U.S. citizens. He said, I drive a bus my whole life. And now my son has a shot of becoming a member of the United States Congress. Where else in the world could we have our story? But where else in the world could any of us have our story? Regardless of our background, where we come from, what side of the aisle we sit on? We have the privilege and opportunity to sit here today as part of a historic moment, fighting for what we believe. The answer of where else is nowhere else. Only here. I trust Kevin to fight for that American Dream. Because he's a product of it. We're all a product of it. He gets it. And understands that a government accountable to the people is the best tool to ensure that our future generations continue to have a real shot at the American Dream. So let's be proud of our stories. Let's be grateful to God for it all. And let's get to work to ensure that everyone has the same opportunity to write their own story. Being a representative isn't a job title. It's a job description. The eyes of the world are honest as we are airing our grievances. That's the cost of leadership. The leadership that comes from this body. So let's act like it. Let's step up to that calling. That our country needs and our districts expect from us. I am confident we will resolve this issue and will stand united to fight for the values that matter to the American people. The American people who sent us here, to tackle inflation, to protect our border, to hold the executive branch accountable. It's time to do the job we were entrusted to do, to get results for the American people that sent us here. And the best person to lead us in this journey and in this fight to defend the American Dream for all. This is Kevin McCarthy. And I am proud to stand here before you today as the first naturalized citizen in the history of Arizona to win a congressional seat. Proud of the work of my parents, my dad, who drove a bus for most of his life, my mom, a homemaker. We grew up in the two bedroom apartment. They didn't own a home until I was in college. But my story is not unique. I wash cars with my dad in the same neighborhood that our office sits today. We're not here celebrating one particular story. We're here celebrating the American opportunity only found here being born from this body as well as the opportunities of our country have gone. In all of you in this room have that story. I strongly believe that we all have a car wash story. The story where we began. And in spite of all the challenges and spite of all the obstacles, we are here. And each one of us are a testament to the opportunity and the greatness of this country. And that is why we are here. And I strongly believe that Kevin McCarthy is the person to lead this body in this new fight, this next 118th Congress. So, at the direction of the Republican Conference, I advance the name of Kevin McCarthy as the next speaker of the House of the 118th Congress.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Arizona Week:  Arizona-Mexico Commission Director Juan Ciscomani Talk Mexico Relationship
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: The governments of Arizona and Sonata have labeled this area as a mega region, a system of economies supporting each other. At a recent buy-nationals summit, the governments agreed to continue collaborating with one another, despite what's been talked about at the national level. I recently spoke with Juan Siscomani, his governor Doug Ducey, senior advisor for regional and international affairs. It's extremely important. Mexico is by far our number one trading part, times four. So it's not even close for the second one. When we look at the trade that we do with Mexico, we break it down in exports and imports. Over $8 billion is what we do in exports with Mexico. And just around $7.2 billion in imports. So we export more than we import in this relationship, Arizona wins. Just to put it in perspective, Mexico trades more with Arizona than they do with the entire country of Germany. So we are a key partner for them as they are to us. So the mutual, the combined, I would say, import an export relationship with Mexico almost reaches $16 billion for the state. Huge. It's responsible for creating about 100,000 jobs directly here in the state of Arizona, plus the indirect jobs that it does as well. So the numbers prove it. This is an important relationship economically and trade and also cultural that we have with Mexico. Some of the talking points that came out were the fact that regardless of what is happening on the national scale, it seems like Arizona and Mexico will continue to work together. Yeah, yeah. We will continue this. We're not turning back. We will continue the course. This has been the priority for the governor since day one. His first international mission trip was to Mexico City five, six months after he was in office, which is what opened the door to the kind of relationship we have now. At that point, Governor probably hadn't been elected yet. But as soon as she was elected, the governor gave her a call and that started with a great relationship, which became a partnership and is now a friendship. And that kind of relationship that we enjoy, we're not going to turn back on. It's important for the state, but it's also important for our overall relationship. The governor always says, as he says, relationship has mattered. And the stronger we keep them, the better prepare we are to phase the challenges. So the national environment and the national message that is going out there would affect us if we didn't have established relationships the way we do. How does the governor handle? We have a Republican president who's not particularly enthused about the relationship with Mexico, a Republican governor who's pushing for it. So where is that balance? Well, the governor is strong and believing on the role of governors and states. And each state sets their own tone with the relationship with Mexico. Because we have the ability to trade with them directly, which is great. So the governor has been very strong on keeping a positive and open relationship with the White House. At the same time reassuring our friends in Mexico that Arizona is open for business. We are open. We want to continue this relationship. And we want to continue to attract companies. As we've been attracting them from California and other states that we're competing with, we want to make sure that our companies here in Arizona have the ability to do business and trade with our companies in Mexico. So there's a very specific role for the state government to play here. The private sector plays a key role and they've done that and they've done very well. But there's also a point where we need the governor's input and leadership and platform to say, hey, we're open and that attracts business. Are there contingencies in place should NAFTA undergo some sort of change? Well, sure. What we trust is that we have a seat at the table with the White House as they look at this issue. The governor has been invited to different national platforms, big national platforms like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the Woodrow Institute, Mexico Center. And he's being recognized and acknowledged and tapped as that trade governor. The governor has been able to, as you said, being from the Republican Party and maintained a good positive relationship with the White House and also with Mexico. Those are not mutually exclusive. We can keep a good relationship with both. And the governor has been very strong on promoting that with Mexico. And we hope that that's an example of what other states can do as well, especially as we carry on with Sonora, that is our number one and main partner within Mexico. But as we have the Arizona Mexico Commission, that's exactly what that is. The Arizona entire Mexico Commission. So we want to move also beyond Sonora because there's a lot of opportunity with Mexico. One of the big headlines that came out of the summit was the port of Rocky Point. Yes. How close is that to being completed? The port is about 50 percent done. This actually port was started by the previous administration in Sonora. It went through some trouble there and just was stopped for a little bit. But now they're continuing under the leadership of Governor Pavlovich. She has great relationships with her federal side as well. And that's what's helped speed up the port conversation. This is a great opportunity for the region of Lorraine because they are going to be attracting hundreds of cruise ships into that region. What that means is we're promoting the two nation, the destination. They can go to Rocky Point, unload the cruise ships there. Our people also can go down and catch the cruise ships there. But in the aspect of trade, Ermesea, which is the main capital of Sonora, the capital of Sonora in Main City, it's about six hours away from Rocky Point. Phoenix is three hours away from Rocky Point. So when they look at their supply for anything the cruise ships are going to need from tablecloths to service to any of that, they're looking at us to do that. So this is a great opportunity for areas on the companies to be suppliers for this expansion of the port. And then we signed an MOU with Sonora about this. The governor is committing to work together to co-promote this cruise ship port and formed working groups from transportation, tourism and economic development of how we can push this. Sonora takes that document, goes to Mexico City and says, this is the agreement we have. Let's speed up the money that is already allocated for this project because they need the federal input and finances to complete this project. But with the document that we signed last week, that's what they take over to say, we're getting there. Let's push this money down. Is the infrastructure in place though in Mexico and here in Arizona to sustain this type of commerce? Great question. There are several points there. First of all, the port of Lucville and Sonora, which is the point that we cross to go to Rocky Point. We've invested millions of dollars on the Arizona side to widen the lanes once across into the US side. Mexico sees that and Sonora acknowledges that we've made an investment and they need to make some investments on their side as well. The travel time to Rocky Point, it's over two hours on the Arizona side and a little less than an hour on the Mexico side. So the majority of the road travel is going to be on our side for Rocky Point. They have that investment to make, which is part of the request that they have for the federal government. They said the kind of agreements that the governors meet about and say, this is where we're at, how can we continue to push this forward? It's about to happen in Arizona that suddenly there's this push, there's this economic strength that's really by national to create cargo and commerce that's going to be flowing freely across the border. Sure. I think, again, it starts at the top with leadership of Governor Ducey and saying Arizona's open for business. This wasn't just a campaign slogan. It wasn't just something that we wanted to get people excited about. It's something that he's living day to day and the administration is fully focused on that. I can tell you by being part of a senior staff, that whatever we do, whatever lengths that we look at, the entire situation is going to be about, how do we create jobs? How do we improve workforce development? How do we improve education? How do we strengthen the livelihood of our citizens in Arizona? That message is out there. The governor's out there promoting it in California and other states, even in Texas, winning projects over to come to Arizona because of the good business climate, low regulation that we've been tackling. And quite frankly, the resources that we have by having Sonora as our good partner in the neighbor in the entire country, all that is just positive messages. And then we also have the policy to back it up. That's a very powerful combination that we enjoy in Arizona. This is our time. This is Arizona's time. No question about it and we're taking full advantage of it. Okay. Thank you so much. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Arizona NAFTA outlook
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Leaders in Arizona remain optimistic about a new NAFTA deal, and in recent years they've made inroads with officials in Sonora and Mexico City. Senior advisor to Governor Doug Ducey Wants his comani told us how those gains are playing out in Arizona. The good news here is that Governor Poblovich has a very strong relationship with Mexico City, as we do with Washington, D.C. Now the advance that we have even on top of that is that Governor Ducey has developed a very strong relationship as well with Mexico City. Mexico sees the Governor as a friend and as someone that has been able to find mutual common interest and shown mutual respect and the conversations that are going on is how do we strengthen this, how do we expand this? partisan_rally_speeches.title: LaMalfa Remarks on ESA Modernization
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Well, thank you, Mr. Newhouse, for your leadership on this and providing this time for us here to see you need to be able to talk about this issue in a very real and constructive way. And, you know, the ESA passed in 1973, I think, with a pretty strong bipartisan effort signed by President Nixon. Very well-intentioned at the time, as were some of the other protection measures that were put in place. And as we saw the other day here with the changing of the Lotus rules, the Water's the United States, over time, regulations can get out of control. They can be used for politics. They can use for controlling people. And for NIMBYism, for no growth and all that. And I think that's really where these have expanded into. And so our job is to provide oversight. Our job is to provide course corrections. Make sure the ship is on the course that was intended 40 plus years ago. And so the package of reforms that are being talked about by my colleagues and the bills that are being offered aren't here to gut the Endangered Species Act or to eliminate species. It's to bring back that course control, course correction that we're looking for. So, though it was signed 40 years ago, it is our job to constantly monitor and make sure it's working. We've talked about earlier, 3% of the species have been listed that were listed have recovered. Now, 3% doesn't give you a very good batting average, I think, in any league. So, that would be considered a failure. It's not because of lack of effort or lack of spending, certainly in my own state of California, or species have been listed. We have issues with fish, with delta smelt, with salmon. And yet, the trillions of gallons of water that are expended, flushing the delta each year to find a lower result. Only two smelt have been caught in their check traps in the last five quarters, I think. That doesn't show success, but it shows a lot of damage to the people that need that water for other purposes as well. So, let's find and focus on things that are going to be helpful to the species to be recovered and doesn't have to damage people in their livelihoods along the way. Reform is necessary to refocus the efforts of the federal government to help them recover more timely. One of them long time listed in Northern California, the Valley Elderberry Longhorn Beetle was listed for approximately 40 years. In yet in 2012, the Fish and Wildlife Service was saying, okay, we think it's time to pull that from the list, let's do the work involved to remove it from the list, because they'd seen some success in that time period. The beetle now has had the listing of the beetle, and an important part that we don't talk about enough is what's known as critical habitat. Critical habitat is any host, plant, or other vehicle for a possible endangered species that might take residents there. So, the bush itself, the Elderberry bush, any one of those basically cannot be touched, because it might be potential habitat for traveling Elderberry Beetle, although maybe not have ever been tracked in that particular area. Yet, every single bush, it's a battle, it's a fight. Now, why are we fighting over the bushes? It's because many of these grow in floodplain areas, on levees, that need to be maintained, rebuilt, upgraded. We have a lot of potential flood in Northern California, indeed, there wasn't so much potential as several times, we've had bad floods result, and I would mention in the Ube City Marysville area, two very big floods in 1996 and 1997, that happened from crumbling levees. Well, why don't they maintain the levees, because they can't. It's getting the permits, getting through the process, and then being able to forward it by the time you've done that with all the requirements that are put on to maintain this habitat, to maintain these Elderberry bushes in this case, makes it cost prohibitor for these local levee districts to be able to do their job. So what happens? Nothing happens. And so, in 1986, giant flood, hundreds, thousands of homes in 1996, and 1997 happened again. If the lesson wasn't learned 11 years later, 1997 happened again in the Ube City Marysville area, and at this point, three lives were lost in addition to all that other damage. Three lives lost needlessly, because we couldn't learn the lessons and get the permits done to get the levee weren't done. Why does that have to be? Because of roadblocks, because of endless lawsuits and slow moving bureaucracies that won't issue the permits and help with the funding that needs to get done, especially for what they have wrought on the costs. So finally, after all that was litigated, the government had to pay approximately $400 million in damages for the losses of life and property in these floods. Pretty disgusting, but still, every single bush is litigated as a potential for critical habitat, even though there may not ever be one of the species you're talking about, in this case, the Valdi Elderberry Longhorn Beetle that might potentially use it. So what happened with the delisting in 2012? Well, they finally gave up because of litigation and about how they do the sampling of the beetle. They said, well, we can't tell if it's the Valdi Elderberry Longhorn Beetle or the California Elderberry Longhorn Beetle that might be making these boreholes in the plants and in the ground there. So they just give up and say, we're not going to delist it anymore. Similar to the situation where my colleagues are talking about with the Wolf, with the Grey Wolf. You can find plenty of Grey Wolf all over the upper Midwest and those other states, yet the standard seems to be in the endangered species act, you have to find two or four mating pairs in every single county, otherwise it's still listed as endangered in California or where else. The rules have gone too far. So we need caps on the attorneys fees that make it not such an incentive for environmental groups to use this as a way to get paid, as well as a way to stop progress, stop things that people need. So I hope this package of bills at least can be a light and example of a direction where we're trying to take back to reasonableness and how the endangered species act is interpreted and used. Not abused, not used as a weapon, weaponized against what we need for flood control to save people's lives, water storage. If we're going to play the climate change game, then we need to be able to have more of these tools available to us to store water, right? So this would certainly help if we had more input from our local stakeholders on this who actually know how to get a project done. Finally, the Mary's Royal UBCD area they're talking about using local districts and local districts after a lot of roadblocks were overcome. So finally, the last bit, which is up to the Army Corps of Engineers, is going to be completed in that area of rebuilding the levees and putting the slurry wall in that's going to make them much less likely to erosion and blowing out. In 2020, the last piece is going to be done. If Army Corps stays on schedule, their own schedule, their own unique schedule. This many years after those two floods. So I commend the great work it's been done up to this point, but how many needless years of risk in these flood zones have to happen because we can't get out of our own way because of a permit or because somebody's interpretation of a critical habitat for a creature that doesn't even show up to these cram... ...it's critical habitat areas. I'm tired of fighting the fight against people that don't seem to care how it affects the people that they govern. So this is a true effort that everybody can see to reform this act into something that actually works for people, works for the species and gets a little better batting average than 3% recovery rate, which is pathetic, especially for the trillions of gallons of water that we lose to the Delta each year. The risk we have for people in flood zones, the high cost, the loss of potential, and the anguish all that brings. So I'm glad we had this time to be able to share this with the public that's watching and our colleagues that are hopefully listening that we can reform the act and still have it pursue the goals, making the endangered species that we talk about. Come off those lists because they're thriving once again. We have seen some successful examples, the bald eagle, so if I can see outside my window at my home and my rice field there, that's pretty tremendous. But we've got to get our batting average up, especially when you look at what it's costing society and loss potential and unfortunately sometimes and loss lives. So Mr. Newhouse, I appreciate the time and I appreciate it.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Huffman: Repealing crude oil export ban = Congress selling out
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Thank you Mr. Sir. Gentlemen from California is recognized for five minutes. Thank you. Let me begin with the usual stipulations. This is the final amendment to the bill. It won't kill the bill or send it back to committee. When this is adopted, the bill will immediately proceed to final passage as amended. So there's no procedural reason to oppose this motion to recommit. Let's talk about the substance. Now we have heard a lot of debate this morning about the need to give big oil, the most profitable industry in the history of the world, yet another advantage. For years, Americans have been told that we have to drill, baby drill. The theory that we always hear is that we need to extract every barrel of oil from every acre of American soil to keep gas prices low and to provide, quote, energy security. But as soon as American gas prices started to drop, the curtain was raised and the truth was revealed. The real reason for drill, baby drill, surprise, surprise was to get big oil the chance to maximize their profits on the world market. It's not enough that they've been able to game the tax code for a century with billions of dollars of tax breaks not available to other taxpayers or businesses. It's not enough that they continue to enjoy access to our public lands and waters for oil drilling, even though they're no longer paying into the land and water conservation fund. The longstanding law that expired at the beginning of this month. As a reminder, for the past 50 years, the Land and Water Conservation Fund was an agreement, a compact, between the American people and big oil. It said that when we let oil and gas companies drill and profit from drilling in federal waters, they have to dedicate a fraction of the profits, just a fraction to protect our great outdoors for future generations. The deal is they have to dedicate a fraction of those profits to protecting our great outdoors for future generations so that our grandchildren will be able to hike and hunt and fish in our parks and wildlife refuges. The Land and Water Conservation Fund was allowed, shamefully allowed, to lapse at the beginning of this month and the majority hasn't scheduled a single vote or even a hearing to get it back on the book. No, all of these concessions to oil and the gas industry are not enough for this house. With today's bill, the house majority is saying that American oil and gas companies can drill more, export more, and realize even greater profits no matter the environmental consequences, no matter the consequences to health and safety. That is breathtaking in its devotion to the oil and gas industries agenda. Now, my motion to recommit would ensure that the President and Federal Government agencies charged with protecting human health, the environment and public safety, can continue to do their job that constituents rely on them to do specifically. With this amendment, we'll ensure that bedrock, health and safety laws like the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Act that laws like that will not be cast aside in favor of big oil's desire to sell more crude overseas. Now, if you think about it, this is a very straightforward amendment. So, I just want to ask my colleagues a question. Should crude oil exports trump the Safe Drinking Water Act? We need to ensure pipeline safety and so, my colleagues, I urge you to vote yes on this MTR to improve this bill and I yield back.

partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: It is absolutely an honor to be with you here tonight for your annual gathering. I want to start by observing what a difference a year can make. Last year at about this time, my constituent, a Washington Post correspondent that was just reference named Jason Resion, was actually imprisoned and being held hostage at Evan prison in Iran. Now we fast forward to this year. And right now, Jason is free to say and write whatever he pleases. He is enjoying a nimen journalism fellowship at Harvard, living there with his wonderful wife, Yegi. Now, Jason went to high school just a few blocks. Yes. Jason went to high school just a few blocks from my district office in Marin County, California. And he had originally gone to Iran in order to connect with his own family heritage, and also as a journalist to write very humanizing stories about a country that frankly is not very well understood by most Americans. For that, for the crime of being a journalist, he was imprisoned and spent 539 days in one of the world's most notorious prisons. Now when we learned in January that Jason was finally going to be released as part of a painstakingly negotiated prisoner exchange, I had the privilege of joining Jason's family and his Washington Post employers in Germany to welcome him back to the free world. I did not know Jason before this ordeal brought us together, but we have actually become good friends now. And I want to tell you, the American Iranian community should be very proud of this young man. He exhibited poise and character before, during, and after his ordeal at Evan Prison, and his remarkable combination of intelligence, thoughtfulness, gentle wit, and modesty make him a uniquely compelling and likable person. Jason and his wife, Yegi, should never have been detained in Iran. He should never have lost 18 months of his life in a prison where he was regularly subjected to physical and psychological abuse. This young couple should not have had their lives turned upside down, but the fact that they are free today is a blessing. And I want to extend a very heartfelt thank you to NIAC for your work to help secure their freedom. Now, I ask advocacy on Jason's behalf was absolutely exemplary.
