partisan_rally_speeches.title: Evolution of Telehealth // Rep. Doris Matsui (D-CA)
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: We'd like to welcome Congressman, Congressman Woman, excuse me, Doris Matsui, a member of the Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee. She is a leader on the Bipartisan Connect for Health Act, which addresses a number of telehealth policies. Congresswoman, thank you for joining us, Bob. Thanks, Katie. Thanks, Congressman, for joining us this morning. Thank you. You've introduced bipartisan legislation on healthcare, which is hard to do. Well. And it's with Bill Johnson of Ohio. Can you tell us a little bit about what that legislation would do and where it is in the Congress right now? OK. Bill Johnson, I have been doing a lot of things together. And actually, in technology, we seem to be able to work together really well with the other side on telehealth of Bill Johnson. And also, we're at the Dothry when I work with Spectrum. But what we're trying to do, Bill Nye, is essentially to actually move forward with ensuring that we can have more access to telehealth. And the way we're doing it is that we already passed Medicare Advantage as far as being able to use telehealth there. What we're trying to do is really kind of attack the big one in which is Medicare fee for service, which is difficult because CMS, HHS believes that, or CBO, believes that it's going to be cost more, essentially. It used more services. But in fact, what we like to do is give the Secretary sort of to waive certain restrictions so that he can decide what type of services can be paid for fee for service, reimbursement, rather. And then let them decide and let the actual decide at that point. So we feel, in essence, because that is really the big one to attack. And if we do that and move that forward, it really breaks open a lot of reimbursement issues. What do you see in your district? What are you hearing from your constituents? And we talk about acronyms of CBO and HHS. And what do you see at the ground level of telehealth and telemedicine that's actually helping patients where technology is an asset? Well, you know, nowadays, technology's all around us. I mean, our personal lives, we use it all the time. And so I believe that, in essence, people want to see this more in health care and make it more efficient. And certainly, that's one of the aspects of lowering the cost, too. And I believe it can be safe and secure and cost-saving, too. If, in fact, we allow patients to monitor themselves, in essence, especially chronic diseases like diabetes. And also, when you think about the fact that there are deficiencies in really reaching out to specialists or primary care doctors, and their barriers of geography and also transportation. So why not allow individuals to really do maybe video conferences, be able to do things electronically, so that the patients themselves feel like they have the opportunity to access health care efficiently. And during the time that they can actually do it, too, a lot of people cannot have in-person care. I mean, that's just the way it is, particularly rural areas, even urban areas where particular older folks can't get around as much. So I think from Medicare in particular. And also, we're looking at it in behavior health. I think that is so important, because there are some behavior health provider shortages. And in this way, a person can contact their psychologists and be able to have a conversation or be able to be assisted in a way that is timely. And with particular behavior in mental health, sometimes you need that right away. And it's difficult to get to your health care provider, your mental health provider. And in this way, you can assist a person with their health care, mental health care, in a timely manner. What is the effect of access to broadband? I mean, everybody come in Washington and New York and the Northeast thinks, well, everyone has access to the internet, but it's really not the case. How big a problem is that? I think it's a big problem. It really is, because we can't have even an urban area. I mean, most people think an urban area has broadband. Not all the time is that true, because they're underserved areas in the urban areas. But particularly rural areas, it's difficult to have broadband out there. Careers don't want to be there. It doesn't costly. So that's where we have to incentivize the carriers to be out there, in essence. And so that's where we look at wireless and things like that. And so the rural areas are really areas where we really believe broadband is going to be necessary for them to not only have the health care that need and deserve, but for economic development also. You remember the energy and commerce telehealth working group? Yes. What are the priorities of that group and how often do you meet, et cetera, et cetera? It's a group that was put together by Chairman of the Washington, when he was chairman. And it's a group of us who really look at these issues of health and technology and try to move bills forward. And we've been very successful to do that, and opening up the discussion, in many cases, too. Because there are privacy aspects here that people are concerned about. And we do have to deal with that with cybersecurity, because we have to look at what we do as far as making sure the platform in health care works for this, and especially when we're talking about electronic health records, which are necessary. And that's one of the things we're incentivizing, too, to a great degree. We have a piece of it in the opioids bill, which should be coming up this week, in which we're incentivizing behavior health providers to use and adopt by using some of the center payments, just as we did with hospitals and doctors, and left them out as far as behavior health. This was some time ago, though, with the high-tech act. So it's really concerning to all of us, particularly now, that we have really addressed more thoroughly, and hopefully more carefully, mental health care. It's being on parity with physical health. In 2017, according to a recent study, 71% of health care providers use some type of telemedicine pool, which is pretty good. But how can that number get higher? I need to get higher. I think the problem is a lot of, there are problems, I think, in communicating, too. We have different systems. And they're working through that. But also, I think people are sort of concerned about privacy aspects. And I think that has to be resolved. We like to see something take place in HHS, and have definitely some security aspect. And have a regulation? No, I think really having, I used to, I had to build this, I'm going to do this again, where we really have somebody at the level of the Assistant Secretary being in charge of this. Because I believe that there are certain areas that people feel like they're siloed. And I really feel that we need to have an expert there who understands what is going on to assist the health care providers. How can CMS and stakeholders help the situation and provide more access and work together in a way? Well, CMS has to be much more flexible. And I think they have been put to a certain degree, too. And that's why we want to really incentivize, have them incentivize, for instance, the behavioral health providers, to really use and adopt a lot of the electronic health records, which they aren't right now. So we like them to do that and to really open it up so that it'd be easier to do it. Now, you can do this at a level where you can have demonstration projects. And I think those kinds of things are really efficient and they really do prove something. And both Democrats and Republicans like that. Because you're looking at it to see if it proves that. And then you can expand it. Is there a lot of news this week? But actually, the government is not going to have a shutdown by partisan bill, a funding bill that passed. What some of us would like to do is expand it even further, particularly because a lot of the payment for opioids, at least in the sense of behavior health, is to mitigate. And we need to look at Medicaid and know that that is a vehicle which a lot of these things are paid for. And so even though we are an agreement with the fact that we have to address opioid crisis and we're doing things, it's still at the edges yet. We need to look at the whole situation and move forward. But it is good that we're addressing it. And as I said, technology, the technology subcommittee, we really do work very well together. It could just more regional differences than partisan differences. And many times I represent urban suburban area. So I work with my rural area colleagues because I've got the population. And many times we can help each other when we work through some of these things. Because if we can get help for each, then we're both winning. And a few minutes we'll open up to questions. So think of your questions. One of the big questions heading into the crucial stretch here about 40 days away in midterms is the house going to flip to the government director. To your party, do you think the house is going to flip this fall? Well, I'm not going to be a prognosticator. I would just say that I'm quietly confident. But listen, it's a long time. 40 days is a long time in politics. And so we're just going to work every single day. Each of us. And I'll leave it there. Health care, though, Democrats have been talking a lot this election year about health care. Two part question. Number one, is it the biggest issue that you hear in your district? And number two, should Democrats win? Would that be a number one, number two, number three, top three priorities? All of us are hearing about health care in different ways. And so it's a big issue. That and jobs, which we're addressing also. But yes, health care is something that we start out with if we're over-care act. And looking forward to, as we address, all of the ultimate aspects of the costs over time and using technology, which we haven't used as well as we probably could, to use that to address some of the costs also, and the convenience. And also, I think we get better health care that way, too. A little bit up for questions in the last few minutes of this segment. So if you have a question, please raise your hand. My question for you is, do you guys have any views on removing the restrictions of 1834M? Which one is that one? That one is for telehealth regulations, basically focusing on different things from originating sites, health plans, where we're doing this. Oh, yes, right. We're addressing that. Particularly a piece of it has been addressed in the opioids bill, as it is part of the opioids bill, as we move forward. And it really is right now, just for the opioids, we'd like to expand it out further. And that's part of what we intend to do. This is part of having some of this lifted by the Secretary of HHS, and the wave some of these conditions. And so we believe in making progress in that area, and the originating sites, and things like that at the first step. Other questions? How has it been working with the Trump administration on health care? Well, I haven't necessarily been working with the Trump administration on health care. I have been working with my colleagues on the Energy and Commerce Committee. And it's been an interesting, because there's been a lot previously, all that repealing replace, that never happened really. They did the repeal, but they never did replace, and that didn't pass anyway. So I think it's been quieter. So we have been focusing on the aspects that we can work together. And I mean, that's really very important. And understanding that there are aspects of it, where, in fact, I mentioned Medicare and Medicaid. And when the opioid crisis came about, which is interesting, because we, in my district, were the crisis maybe a couple of years ago, addressing it. But it didn't come that way in the rest of the country. So it's particularly on Northeast and the East. It started really taking hold. So when your district didn't really hit the South, the South, the South, the South. It did hit, but it hit earlier. OK. I mean, I think those are the kinds of things. We really have to continue the address. I mean, we know with health care, nothing's ever completely done. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Future Forum Discussion on Tech Diversity, 4-13-2016
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Thank you Mr. Speaker. I rise today on behalf of the future form to provide an update on our past years work and activity and to discuss the work we must still do to move America's Millennials forward. Yesterday April 12th marked the one-year anniversary of future form and what a year it's been. I encourage everyone at home to follow along as we talk about these issues this afternoon at hashtag future form on Twitter or Instagram and Facebook. Send us your questions I'll look at them live here on the floor and talk about them and continue the dialogue beyond today's conversation. Our membership has grown from 14 members a year ago when we started to 18 of the house's youngest members. We've traveled to 14 cities now across this great nation from San Diego, California to Manchester, New Hampshire and to most recently last week hosted by representatives to get, pull us and pearl mutter and Denver. We're even joined there in Denver by our house minority whip, Steny Hoyer. On each visit we talked to young people at universities, community colleges, co-working spaces, and startup companies to learn about the issues most important to them. The issues that they are finding as their own personal barriers to success. Overwhelmingly we've heard Millennials across the nation share that they're most concerned about issues relating to student loan debt, college affordability, climate change, and campaign finance reform. I want to talk about a few of these issues and first start with student loan debt. At many of these sites we ask people with a polling app, what issue is most important to you? And across the country the issue that we've seen most often, regardless of what part of the country we are in, what crowd we are in front of has been student loan debt. Now this is an issue that is very personal to me. I just brought my own student loan debt just under $100,000 within the last few months. And I have seen in my own life in my constituents' lives in California's East Bay, and what the people we've talked to with these future form discussions, that student loan debt has put an entire generation into financial quicksand. And it affects almost every life decision that young people are making. The biggest decisions you'll make in your life. The decision to start a family. We are delaying that decision by about five years later than the generation before us. The ability to buy a house. We are perhaps the least home-owning generation America has ever known. The decision and the ability to go out on your own and start your own business. Well actually, Millennial Entrepreneurship is on the decline. From 2014 to 2015, 5% fewer Millennials started a business. How is that? You look at Silicon Valley, you look at Silicon Alley, you look at Silicon Beach, you look up in the Northwest, it's Silicon Forest. You see all of these startups across our country and you think, well, this is the startup generation. In fact, we're more risk averse than you would think. It's because of the student loan debt that we carry and makes it so hard to go out on your own, to find that capital you need, to take that risk, to start a business, to create jobs that will help grow our economy. These are the four issues we're seeing that student loan debt is affecting. Starting the family, buying a home, starting a business, and then finally being able to save. We are also the generation that has saved the least of any generation that has ever come before us. And it makes sense, right? Every month you have approximately 40 million young people with 1.3 trillion dollars in student loan debt, hundreds of dollars each month going out the window, going to pay off this debt, making it very hard for you to rent near where you work, let alone even realize that American dream of home ownership. Now while higher education also remains a worthwhile investment, we have found on our tour that by 2018, 63% of new jobs will require a college education. But here's the problem. The cost of college continues to go up. And one of our biggest challenges, perhaps, is making and having generations that have come before us understand that what they experienced 30, 40 years ago is just not what young people are going through today. It's apples and oranges in terms of experiences. In fact, the cost of college tuition has gone up higher and faster than any other good or service that Americans consume. In California, for example, in the 60s and 70s, if you were qualified and you were able, you could go to a UC University of California school and walk away with essentially a debt-free education. The return on that investment, when Californians and the federal government valued public education as a public good, was a workforce that built the greatest tech and biotech economy that the world has ever seen. The tech economy that drives Northern California, the biotech economy that is striving down in San Diego, the minds that are powering the inventive forces in the entertainment industry down in Los Angeles. That's the return on investment that we received when we treat the education as a public good in California. And you could have a UC degree and walk away with a debt-free education. Now, an issue that is also important to millennials and new to future form and affecting young Americans is the issue of diversity in the tech industry. We love the tech industry in California that has created so many new jobs and a lot of traffic to go with it, but people who are driving to good-paying jobs. Silicon Valley in the Bay Area is at the helm of America's burgeoning tech industry, which is constantly developing innovative ways to interact with in a global environment and compete in the 21st century. These cutting-edge companies are creating new ways to communicate, travel, buy, sell, and listen. But the tech industry is led by some of the best and the brightest our nation has to offer. But there are some statistics about the tech industry I want to share with you that are quite disturbing. The tech industry is not as diverse as California or our country is. Millennials are at the center of this industry. They are the largest generation in the US workforce. By 2020, millennials will make up 50 percent of the global workforce. However, over the past two to three years, major concerns have been raised that tech lacks one major component. Where the largest workforce America has ever known, where the largest and most diverse generation America has ever known, but the tech industry is missing a diverse workforce. Despite making up significant portions of the US population, women and minorities are drastically underrepresented in this industry. Let me give you an example. The tech 2020 initiative we've taken these principles on the road to the boardrooms of some of the biggest names in the tech sector. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Speaker pro Tem Mullin Talks About Legislative Goals for 2016
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Welcome to Capital Connection. I'm Assembly Speaker, Pro Tem, Kevin Mullin, and I'm excited to update you on the 2016 legislative year. Newly elected Assembly Speaker, Anthony Rendon, has appointed his leadership team, and I am honored to be reappointed as Speaker Pro Tem. I plan to continue presiding over floor sessions in the spirit of cooperation and bipartisanship. I am carrying a total of 20 bills this session that address clean tech and biotech, elections and voter access, and two of the most pressing issues in San Mateo County, housing and transportation. Workforce housing is a top policy priority for me this year. San Mateo County and the Bay Area overall is experiencing a perfect storm of circumstances that contribute to rising housing costs. The Bay Area is a great place to live, has a large and growing population, is home to a successful innovation economy, and has high demand for service sector jobs, and yet has a dearth of developable land. The elimination of redevelopment agencies in 2011 hit affordable housing production hard since they were the number one producer of low and moderate income housing. In an effort to address the lack of a coherent statewide housing policy, I have introduced AB-2502, which would reinstate a law allowing local governments to pass inclusionary ordinances to require developers to include a certain percentage of newly constructed housing units for low and moderate income renters. I have also been appointed by the speaker to serve on a housing working group, and I support allocating a portion of the 2016-17 General Fund budget to affordable housing programs. On the transportation side, I will continue to work with leaders in the assembly to provide a comprehensive solution to the funding shortfall for street and highway repair, as well as public transit. I have introduced AB-230, which will allow CalTrain and Bart to process low to mid-cost procurements in a more efficient manner. I have also introduced AB-2126, which will increase the number of projects CalTrain can build using the construction manager general contractor method from 6 to 12, which will increase opportunities to reduce costs and expedite congestion relief projects in the state. I am also exploring avenues to provide a dedicated revenue source of funding for CalTrain. While these and other bills are now on their way through the committee process, the budget is a significant topic of discussion since June 15th is the deadline to pass a balance budget. In my role as speaker pro-Tam and as a member of the budget committee, I am committed to working with our leadership team and my Bay Area colleagues to craft a bipartisan approach that balances spending on vital priorities, pays down debt, and addresses our long-term fiscal liabilities. The governor's proposed budget takes a prudent approach, setting aside dollars for critical healthcare funding, increases education funding, and allows for a $2 billion allocation to the rainy day fund and pays down debt. And while there is no question we need to ensure a strong reserve in the event of an economic downturn, we cannot stand by while our middle class is continually priced out of housing and forced to move further and further away from where they work. I remain committed to crafting a state budget that balances the pressing need for infrastructure and transportation improvements while also making sure we address the massive gap in funding for workforce housing left by the dissolution of redevelopment agencies. In spite of these challenges, I have every confidence that working together we will be on track for a sixth consecutive on-time balance budget. I look forward to sharing more in the next edition of Capital Connection. Until then, you can learn more about my bill package by following me on Facebook or by visiting my website. Thanks for watching.

partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Democrat Kevin Mullin is the new representative for California's 15th Congressional District, one of nearly 80 new House members in the 118th Congress. He told C-SPAN about the advice his predecessor former representative Jackie Spear gave him coming into the job and about what he was doing in state and local government before being elected to Congress. So I was a California State Assembly member. I was the Speaker of Pro-Tam of our California State Assembly, the number two officer in the Assembly for 10 years. And prior to that, I was a City Council Member and Mayor in the city of South San Francisco, which we like to remind people of the birthplace of biotechnology. If you fly out of SFO, you'll see South San Francisco, the industrial city, big white letters on our sign hill. That is my hometown and I was a small business owner before that. I had a small communications business and I was a legislative aide to Jackie Spear. My predecessor in Congress, when she was a state legislator, I worked for her as an aide. Did she give you any advice when you decided to run for this seat? Oh absolutely. There was no shortage of advice, thankfully, from Congresswoman Jackie Spear. She is an icon on the San Francisco Peninsula, given her 40 years of public life. She's got an incredible personal story. She is a household name to say the least. And frankly, it was surprising to everybody, frankly, when she announced her retirement. She suggested that I run. She had been watching me not only for my days as an aide to her, but as a state assembly member, state legislator in my own right, and she thought I was a worthy successor. Not always, although I am the product of some kitchen table conversations. My mother when I was growing up was a Republican. My father, a government teacher, is a civil rights era liberal. Government teacher believed in civic participation. So undoubtedly that rubbed off on me. And continue to be interested in civic matters, obviously, as I find myself here at the capital. We have special education teachers that are dealing with the cognitive dysfunction that arises by virtue of the pollution. We have social workers dispersing all the benefits that are necessary because lots of folks can't now work by virtue of these health problems. We have police officers and prison guards now being hired in ever hiring numbers to deal with the fraying social fabric as more and more folks can't work. That's the downstream approach. It's really complicated, right? There's a lot of things you have to do by virtue of these health problems. Now, of course, if you don't like that downstream approach, there's another way to go. And that would be the upstream approach and just end the pollution. So I would argue that that's a useful metaphor for understanding how we take on poverty as well. So what do we do? Well, we treat all the symptoms of poverty. And that's a complicated job, right? We hire social scientists, again, a full employment policy for us to track the many and multifarious consequences of poverty. And there are lots. So we lay them out in paper after paper. We hire nurses and physicians to deal with all the health problems. And there are many that arise by virtue of poverty. We hire social workers to disperse benefits and otherwise handle the multifarious problems that arise because of poverty. We, of course, hire police officers and prison guards because we have to be honest about it. One of our main poverty policies is warehousing the board. And that's to repair the institutions that are creating all this poverty. So I want to lay out an ambitious agenda about how you might actually do that. And so I want to talk about this upstream approach. And I think we know in general terms what's to be done. But the devil here, as always, is in the details. And so I want to lay out some of those details. And if we're going to really get serious about taking on poverty, and I think we should, we've got to get it right. And it took a long time for us to even contemplate the possibility of undertaking another full on war. I think the time is right to do that now. But we've got to do it. We've got to get it right. But there's another, so I'm not going to talk about that force. But it's a backdrop that we have to take on if we're thinking about how to reduce poverty substantially. But the other force that I don't think is as well appreciated is rising commodification. And it's really these two forces operating together that give rising inequality its teeth. One way we all know that is use the market, right? So if you have the resources, the money, you buy those goods and services, right? The other way, though, is that they're just seen as a prerogative of group membership. That everyone universally is given those goods and services. And we allocate them to members of that group automatically. And by rising commodification, I mean that it's that first approach using the market to allocate goods and services that's increasingly commonly used. So you need the money to buy goods, services, and even opportunity. OK? So let me give you a really simple example, an example about which no one would care in and of itself, but makes it clear what I'm talking about. So what was once the public good, you're going to have got to pay for them. That's the decline of public goods through this simple example. But there's another force at work, what I would call the decline of public lottery. So it used to be the case that you could get a bulkhead seat or an exit row seat just by lucky, just by luck. That you could log on a bit earlier than others and just get it or you'd line up earlier and get it. And by luck alone, you'd get those seats. But I think it's a, it's, it demonstrate what's going on more, more broadly. And so I want to talk about just two examples of the decline of public goods and how it affects people who are poor and the decline of public lottery. So let's start with public goods. Just one example, but an important one. I don't know much time. But it used to be that just by virtue of being born, you would have access, by and large, to loving child care from your mother. That was just a public good. You're born? You get that. Now, of course, we have a two-erinder family and that's wonderful and great, but let's just think about what that means for poor people. And we know that high quality early childhood has immense implications for, for, for down the road productivity. And so if you don't have access to it, if you don't have the money to put on the table, that's a problem. So that's the decline of public goods. It's just one example, but a, but an important one. What about public lottery? Well, it used to be the case, if you, in like say, 75 years ago, if you were poor, you could actually rent an apartment in a city like Palo Alto. And, and that's like winning the neighborhood lottery, right? Because now your kids would have access to those wonderful Palo Alto public schools, and have all the opportunity that's been afforded to them by virtue of that. Now if you're poor, of course you're locked out of Palo Alto, you're locked out of those high-ventity neighborhoods. And that's a general phenomenon across the US, across California. Poor people are increasingly living with other poor people, and rich people are living with rich people. And that means poor people are locked out of neighborhoods that provide those amenities like high quality public schooling that make it possible for their children to do well. So that's the decline of public lottery. There's no neighborhood lottery anymore, rich, live with rich, poor, live with poor, and that's consequential. Okay, so what do you do? If I operate, so what I'm basically laid out is that opportunity has to now be bought. If you're poor, it's not just that you have less money than the well-off, that's rising income inequality. But it also is the case that you need money increasingly to buy opportunity for your kids. You need money to buy high quality childcare, and that generates opportunity for your kids. You need money to get into high-ventity neighborhoods that allow for high-quality public schooling for your kids. Opportunities for sale. You need money now as a poor person. So then, then was the case in the past, you need money to buy that opportunity for your kids. So, so that's the backdrop. What do you do? So we live in this highly commodified world. Poor people are disadvantaged in two ways now. They have less money than the well-off in relative terms, and they need money more than was the case in the past to buy opportunity for their kids. What do you do? Well, one option is to acquiesce to commodification, if I can put it in scholarly speak, and just transfer money to the poor. You say, okay, look, opportunities for sale, that's where we are, fine. We do commit as a country to providing opportunity to everyone. We think that's very important. And hence, let's provide the poor with the money that they need so that they can buy opportunity for their kids. So that would just be a transfer program. This is, for example, what Tony Blair did in the UK very aggressively. He reduced poverty. But how long did the Blair program last? As long as Blair lasted. And now it's being dismantled. So it was a politically contentious solution to carry out a lot of transfer. Right? So option two, which I think is politically more viable in a country like the US and the UK that has certain sensibilities about these things, is politically more viable to de-commonify, to directly provide opportunities in those junctures where the poor don't have access to them. So I'm going to lay out how you might do that very quickly. I'm almost done. So what you want to do is identify those places where poor children don't have the same opportunities as children born into well-off families have. You identify where that is and they need to deliver directly those opportunities. And so the idea is that in this country, we're committed to the principle that all children, no matter how rich or poor their parents may be, all children should have access to opportunities. Let's figure out where it is that we're not living up to that commitment and deliver those opportunities. And so the idea is that, yeah, the market's wonderful in delivering goods and services as a wonderful mechanism, except when it comes to opportunity. There we think everyone should have it. All kids should have it. Not just those who are lucky enough to be born into rich families, but all kids. And so if we're not living up to that commitment, let's do it. If you're going to be using taxpayer money for this, and I think you're going to have to, you have to make sure that whenever you spend that money, you do it with programs that have been proven to deliver results. So you might say by contrast, the rich can spend promiscuously on their children, European vacation, no problem, finishing school vacation, do it. Maybe it'll have payoff, you're not sure. But you got the money to do it. And so of course, as a parent, you want to do it. Basically, the objective here is to equalize information about how to raise children in healthy ways, deliver information about raising children at both prenatal and postnatal stages. The home visiting program has been shown to be very effective. It's just an information intervention. You're just providing information to folks so that they can carry those healthy practices in a way that have been shown to deliver. Very effective program. Equalizes capacities. Because we know that these types of practices, when played out, generate healthier kids. Equalized capacities can have a profound effect at reducing poverty. But then you got to hand off. That's one way in which opportunities are equalized. But the next way is that early training has to be provided to families that can't afford to put the money on the table. So you directly provide early childhood education to poor children. Because again, been shown that when you do so in a high quality way, immense payoff. It's one that's been put out by my colleague, Carolyn Hockspy. What she's shown is that a lot of poor kids don't apply to colleges that line up well with their with their talents and capacities. They may have a high GPA, very high test scores. But they're not applying to the right types of colleges, the kinds of colleges that will really exploit their talents. If you just provide information to poor kids using social media, for example, provide information, text messaging, provide information to those kids, saying, you know, actually if you apply to Stanford, you'd get in and you'd get a free ride. Poor kids don't have access to that kind of information because they're growing up typically with other poor kids who just don't know what kind of colleges for which they might qualify. Well off kids get that just organically in their neighborhoods by running into other kids who know that information. So there's a plan out there actually. It avoids cash transfers in favor of directly providing services. And we've actually focused group this throughout the state. People are okay with that. They like that approach. Cash transfer, a bit of a problem, direct provision of opportunities. They're all on board. It's consistent with our values. It's all about equalizing opportunity, which is one of our fundamental values, right? We think that kids, no matter how poor their parents may be, should have opportunities. Let's make sure that happens. We've done the simulations that show that if we make these kinds of interventions in an aggressive, full-throated way, we'll substantially reduce poverty. Why? Because we're treating it at the right scale. Most of our program's are way too small, given the magnitude of the problem. Next, it'll be a permanent reduction in poverty, because we're treating it at the source. This is an upstream approach, a permanent reduction in poverty. We always want to end poverty tomorrow, right? And so we have a lot of quick fixes, magic bullets, small programs, flavor of the day programs, because we want to do it tomorrow. It's not going to be tomorrow. It's going to take 20 years. But if we do it, if we commit to that now, in 20 years, we can solve this problem. And that would be an extraordinary thing. partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Hi, I'm Assembly Speaker, Pro Tem, Kevin Mullin, and I'm proud to represent San Mateo County in the California State Assembly. Welcome to another edition of Capital Connection, my video message series, designed to keep my constituents updated on what's happening at the state capital. I'm happy to report that the 2017-18 legislative session is often running. When Governor Brown delivered his state-of-the-state address in January, he urged both houses of legislature to continue working together for all Californians. Over the past six years we have increased support for public schools, increased the minimum wage, served as a world leader in climate change while also closing a massive budget deficit and creating a rainy day fund. Our most recent accomplishment was the passage of SB1, the comprehensive long overdue transportation package that will provide much needed investments in roadways and public transit throughout California. Our transportation infrastructure already had many glaring needs and this winter's heavy rain exposed even more fragile roadways and desperate need of repair. I know San Mateo County residents experienced the deterioration of our roads firsthand and given the work I have done over the past two years to address the poor conditions on Highway 101, I am pleased to let you know that SB1 includes $300 million to address this important stretch of roadway. Passing the transportation package was a major achievement however we still have many pressing issues before us. The 2017-18 budget must be adopted by June 15th. The governor's proposed budget is a generally prudent approach and anticipates declining revenue projections in California based on the unknown economic impact that may result from potential changes in the amount of federal funding under the Trump administration. In spite of these uncertainties we absolutely must find a way to make affordable housing available, particularly workforce housing. So more Californians can live closer to where they work. Our housing crisis continues to spiral at a time when workforce housing is needed most to maintain our economic growth. I am proud to be working with Assembly member David Chu and other legislative colleagues to craft the affordable housing legislation that makes sense and addresses this critical issue. As a member of the budget committee I look forward to working with my assembly and Senate colleagues to build on the governor's budget proposal and craft a sustainable budget with growing out-year reserves and smart investments to strengthen the middle class, reduce poverty and fulfill the promise of access to quality medical care. My legislative package includes a total of 23 bills which focus on the following areas. Elections, social equity, transportation and the innovation economy. I look forward to sharing more details with you in the next edition of Capital Connection. You can also obtain more information on my full legislative package by visiting my website and following me on Facebook. I hope you've enjoyed this edition of Capital Connection. I'd like to invite residents of San Mateo County to contact me by visiting my website and clicking on the contact Kevin button or calling my office with suggestions or feedback. It is an honor to represent you in the California State Assembly and thank you for watching.

partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Let me end with some remarks, a little more personal. You see in our country's history, there have always been two different visions of America, two different strands. There has been leaders like Lincoln who appealed to the better angels of our nature, and there has also been an uglier strand that the country has always had to deal with, whether that strand was xenophobia, or racism, or slavery, or segregation. The great thing about this nation is that the better vision of America always wins out in the long run. I believe, I believe in an America that will compete not by playing to stereotypes, but will compete by striving for excellence. I believe in an America that will not begrudge other nations their success, but will lead by inventing the future. I believe in an America that will not close itself off to the rest of the world, but will embrace the dreams of people around the world. You see, that's the America my parents came to. That's the America. They came in these heavy times in the 1960s. John F. Kennedy calling us to send a man to the moon. This time where people believed in this nation's ability to inspire the world. You know what? I saw a glimpse of that America and these young kids who were knocking doors. I saw it in them. This sense that there's this one place in the world where merit and hard work can take you as far as you want to go. People say this election is about my condo or me, tech versus labor, you know, the democratic establishment versus the Sheryl Sandberg, but you know what? They get it all wrong. They get it all wrong. This election is about something much deeper. This election is about the soul of our nation. What type of America do we want to be? I believe years from now, regardless of the results and I know we're going to do very well in winning November, but I believe years from now when people look back and they look at this room. They will say in this unique city of Kupertino, in this unique city began a unique moment where the children of immigrants from India and Vietnam and China and the Philippines were signed by side with third and fourth generation Santa Clarence to renew a sense of purpose in our nation and restore our democratic ideals, to pave the way for the America that my parents came to, to pave the way for a new great American century. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Ro Khanna's Full Speech: "Rep. Honda's failure to be accessible"
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: So I'd like to start off today with Rokana. Thank you to everyone, all the constituents from the district for taking the time out on a weekday. And thank you to the media for being here to cover this event. This is a very respectful gathering and the purpose is very simple. As I have had the opportunity to campaign for over a year and a half across this district, the best part has been meeting constituents, meeting students and talking to folks. We have done over 190 meeting reads. I've not done over 5,000 doors. And every time we have an open town hall meeting or a meeting read, I will hear something from a constituent or from a person about what they believe, what they want to see happen in this country and take their feedback. What is self-disappointing is that Congressman Honda has not been engaged in this very basic premise of representative democracy. I mean, there was an article in the economist recently, which compared the United States Congress to European nobility, saying that the turnover rate in the United States Congress is less than nobility in Europe. And our founders would be rolling over in their graves if they knew that in a five week recess, where folks are supposed to come and talk to constituents and answer their questions, a congressman has not had a single town hall. Oh no. Now, this is not about Congressman Honda or me. This is about what's wrong with our democracy. We're supposed to meet with people and constituents and take their ideas. We're supposed to answer tough questions about the Middle East or about Ukraine or about why we're losing jobs. And you're supposed to get answers that people may disagree with, but not duck from the debate that is the homework of democracy. And my disappointment with Congressman Honda not doing an answering town halls and questions has very little to do with this campaign. But in my judgment is symbolic, emblematic of exactly what's wrong with American politics, that we no longer have folks who feel any degree of accountability. Other people who represented this new district and I issue even the infamous repeat start, they used to new town halls. You know, Josh covered some of them. They'd be entertaining affairs, but they would subject themselves to voters and the questions that people would have. And I really hope that whatever the outcome of this campaign is, the Congressman Honda will start to hold open public forums, listen to the ideas that people in this district have and take them to Washington and answer the tough questions. And it raises questions why he has been unwilling to do that this entire recess. The second thing is debates. You know, now when I started out this campaign, I admit I was a little naive and I guillistic and I said, let's have Lincoln Douglas style debates and raise the dialogue and Congressman Honda and I can be out there for a couple hours in every city talking about the issues. And honestly, I thought I had very little chance to win, but I thought, okay, let me go and raise the dialogue. Let's raise the issues that concern this district when we started out. But what we have been met with is absolute silence. Not a single debate has taken place since this campaign has begun. And it is just disappointing not again because of this campaign, but it's disappointing for the voters. The voters in this district deserve debates. They deserve an honest, open discussion about the issues. And they don't deserve just one debate rigged close to the election to make sure that someone doesn't make a gap. They deserve an honest, open dialogue about the issues of few debates so they can make an informed choice about who is better representative of their needs. Again, it's not something to score political points. It's something that is so fundamental to the job of a representative Congressman that I hope for his own legacy, Congressman Honda, will listen to the people in this district and engage in those debates. Finally, before I hand it over to some of our speakers, the fundamental thing I think about being a Congressman, it's a pretty vocal job. It's not like being a big shot in Washington. Your job is actually to listen to your constituents and take care of them and listen to their needs and be accessible to them. And folks who work with our campaign know I'll answer Facebook posts at 3 in the morning and I'll answer emails from constituents who have questions. And I love the part of the job that I love most as a candidate is talking to people and meeting them and being able to one day hopefully help work on their issues. And what is disappointing about Congressman Honda is that maybe he started out that way, but there has been a sense where he's lost that. A sense where he's no longer connected to the grassroots to the community listening to them, helping them, helping them with their issues. And I think this stems from a sense of entitlement. And what surprised me most in this whole campaign was how offended, upset Congressman Honda and his supporters have been that I'm even running for Congress. I'm not upset that Congressman Honda is running. I think it's great. I wanted to believe him. But somehow he's upset at this very idea that someone would run. Well let me tell you something in this country. These seats don't belong to these career politicians. They belong to the people. And they have to be earned. The right thing on a Congress has to be earned every two years. All we're asking Congressman Honda with respect is give people the chance to make an informed choice. Present your ideas, present your vision, let us present ours, and then let the people decide who best will represent them. I'm content with that outcome. I hope he will too. And I hope he will show a respect not for me as a candidate, but for the democratic process at a time where our country needs them. Thank you. Thank you to everyone for being here.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Congressman Jimmy Panetta's Remarks on Standing Up for Immigrants
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Mr. Speaker, good evening. I rise today to oppose President Trump's anti-immigrant executive orders. And to share with you why I feel these orders harm the people across my district and ultimately across our nation. I'm here because my grandfather came here as an Italian immigrant back in 1921. He told us that the reason he came here was to give his children a better life. And he wanted a chance to achieve what I think we all know to be the American dream. I'm here in front of you living the reality of that dream. And that is why I strive every day as best as I can to give back to my country and community here in Washington, D.C. and especially on the Central Coast of California. I do that not only because of my grandfather, but because it was our forefathers that made it clear that this is a nation. This is a country based on we, the people. And so to me, in this country, being American means that all of us bear the burden to serve one another and to welcome those, especially those who are willing to come here and share in that responsibility. I believe that we should embrace them. I believe that we should embolden them with the opportunities to share in that American dream. We know that the world looks to the United States for enlightened leadership. But these ill-advised actions send a wrong message about our values as a nation. We are a nation of immigrants. We are stronger because of our diversity and because of the people who have taken the risks to come here just as my grandfather did to live here and to contribute to our country and our communities. On the Central Coast of California, that is the heart and soul of that area. I see hardworking men and women who come to this country to live in it and contribute to it. The two main industries there on the Central Coast are agriculture and tourism. Big industries. There are people, workers, owners who contribute greatly, not only to those industries but to our communities. And they are our neighbors, our friends, our families, our children. They sit next to my two daughters and play with them at school. Clearly without them, my community would be a shell of its former self. I hear the pain in their voices because they feel that this administration's executive orders targets them and makes them feel unwelcome. And I've seen that these types of executive orders drive a wedge in our country and it drives them further away, participating in our community. Before I was sworn in on January 3rd of this year, I was a prosecutor. And before the five and a half years I was there in the Monterey County District Attorney's Office. And in that type of prosecution, as you can imagine, as you know well, it can be very difficult to have witnesses come forward and participate in one of the cornerstones of our country, our criminal justice system. They are intimidated. They are worried about retribution and retaliation. But now from what I've heard is that they are worried not just about criminals, they are worried about the government. The government cracking down on them if they came forward, cracking down on them and sending them back to where they came from. These executive orders discourage participation in our community. But instead, as a nation, we should encourage people to step up, to step forward and to be a part of our criminal justice system. Last weekend I met with community members and I heard directly from them about their concerns. And this weekend, I'm doing it again. I'm holding a town hall to continue this conversation. I believe it is our responsibility to listen to all of our community members and consider the implications of these types of executive orders and the implications that they have on all of our constituents. When the President of the United States was sworn in, he took a note to protect all members of our nation by supporting and defending our Constitution. As a member of Congress, I took a note to support and defend that very same Constitution. And rest assured, I will honor that oath. And I will honor that oath to my grandfather and to this country by fighting and resisting unconstitutional orders from this or any other President. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Valadao: Stop Playing Politics with Water
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Adam Speaker, my constituents have faced drought conditions for years, communities throughout the Central Valley and the entire American West are running out of water for daily use in homes, businesses, and agriculture production. Farmers are being forced to follow their fields and dry out their orchards, and hundreds of thousands of acres will be unable to be planted again this year. Instead of coming to the table to work on real solutions that would give families and farmers in my community the water they desperately need to survive. The majority has decided they would rather play politics with the most critical resource in the valley. Apparently passing political messaging bills to check a box is more important to my democratic colleagues than trying to save the livelihood of thousands of valley farmers trying to put food on the table of Americans across the country. This bill is completely silent on the desperate need for enhanced water storage infrastructure to better prepare us during wet years. It does not cut red tape, decrease time delays, or address increased project costs due to redundant requirements underneath it. The bottom line is this bill is bad policy and it bad policy for the Central Valley. My colleagues don't seem to understand that the fewer agriculture products the Central Valley produces, the worse off our own domestic food supply will be. Reduced ag means more of a reliance on other nations for our food, which is an issue for national security. We must do better to address the severe drought we are suffering through the American West. The Wynn Act which passed by partisan support under President Obama in 2016 provided real relief to valley farmers by increasing operational flexibility of the Central Valley project and the state water project. It also authorized millions of dollars for important water infrastructure projects to improve the current canal, the Delta Mendoza Canal, and the California aqueduct. The Wynn Act was critical to ensuring that valley families in rural communities and across the United States have clean, reliable water. We made great progress because of this legislation. Unfortunately, authorities under the Wynn Act expired in 2021 and this is why I introduced the Renew Wynn Act. To extend storage and operations provisions for the Wynn Act and authorize funds for critical water storage projects. Over three quarters of the Democrats in this house supported the positions in 2016, but this week they refused to include my bill in this so-called drought relief package. They are blocking an actual solution to the crisis in the name of environmental justice. Madam Speaker, where is the justice in letting thousands of valley farmers lose their livelihoods because they cannot get something as basic as water? If this drought bill was truly about solving the water crisis in the west, the House majority would include the Renew Wynn Act in this package instead of actively blocking its consideration. And once again urging the House majority to consider this legislation that will bring water to the people in my community doing everything possible to survive this terrible drought. I urge the Democrat majority to stop playing politics with the resource that the entire country is so reliant on.

When we negotiate with the Senate, the majority leader is there at the table, obviously with the speaker, also the setting the calendar, making sure that items come to the floor and making sure that when they come to the floor, most people agree to them. And having a voice from the valley here, like, kind of McCarthy in that position is a good thing for us. And that's why we have the legislative branch, is to make sure that people are represented and laws are passed that are beneficial to all. And if the president is going to decide to take this route, I think that's going to be hurtful to everybody. I do wish the House would act and start to pass legislation. There has been some that have passed, but there needs to be more. And so I have obviously been advocate for immigration reform. I'm going to continue to be an advocate for it, and I'm going to continue to work to make sure that we carry out our responsibilities as a legislative branch and pass these bills. How are there any talks between you and the gang of aid? The Senate has already passed it, but is there any? The majority later, and the old majority later, Eric Canter, and the transition out of Kevin McCarthy has slowed down some progress right now in the House, but I expect us to still continue to push once things get settled. What have you heard from your constituents regarding that? You know, for the most part, my constituents are very supportive of seeing something done. I think they want it to be fair. They want it to be respectful of those who have tried to follow the laws, but they also want to make sure that we resolve this in a way that doesn't put us in the same position 20 years from now. I mean, you can't pass amnesty. You have to pass a program that helps future flow, resolves the situation we have today, and also protects American workers at the same time. And so that's why it has to be something that covers all those aspects, and that's why I've been supportive of the comprehensive. And what do you think about the humanitarian crisis that has been focused now? Well, the humanitarian crisis that's going on along the border is obviously something very sad that has to be addressed. And that is something that's obviously come around because of a lot of the actions that the President has taken, but at the same time, the lack of direction that Congress has taken as well. We have to make sure that we have clear defined laws that work and that prevent things like this from being seen as an option. And I think that if we did take an active role in fixing the immigration system in general, it would have a much larger role in fixing that issue as well. It's something that has to be resolved, obviously. And with a bunch of kids showing up at our border, it's a very sad situation. But we're going to do our best to try to resolve that in a humanitarian way. President Moan did mention just now part of the reason that has to represent its hominable to pass this is because there's that division between the Tea Party members and moderate conservatives. Do you agree with that? You know, one of the original gang of eight is role Labrador, who actually ran from a majority leader with this port of that wing of the party. And there are aspects across the board of people who understand the immigration system is broken and want to fix it. So I think the President is exaggerating when it comes to that. And as far as the water crisis here in California, what have been some of the steps that you guys have been looking at? Well, obviously, HR 3964 was passed off the floor back in February. The Senate passed their bill a couple weeks ago. And now we've been talking with the Senate to come up with a compromise that works to help solve this problem. The talks are actually ongoing. We have been meeting with the Senate our Senate counterparts. And we're doing our best to come up with a solution. As far as short-term solutions, if our bill had been passed back in February and signed into law right away, we wouldn't be in the mess we're in today. The best we can hope for now is preventing next year from being this bad. And as far as elections, so you're running up against the main inventory, what are you looking forward to in that election? Well, we're going to continue to work hard and do everything we're supposed to be doing. I've been representing the district now for about a year and a half. But as you all saw yesterday, there was about five members that voted against their party and sadly, we're getting closer and closer to that day.
