partisan_rally_speeches.title: The Group S Rally Cars
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: A few months ago, as some of you likely know, I made a short documentary all about Group B and its rise and fall. Briefly at the end, I mentioned Group S. I had advised watching the full video to get a proper breakdown of the subject. But in essence, when Group B was no longer viable to keep running because of the deaths of both spectators and drivers, Feesers shut the whole championship down. The PES pride to this had been planned to be brought in in 1988 to replace Group B. Homologation rules were lessened where 10 cars were required instead of 20 liking Group B, as well as focusing on making it cheaper for manufacturers to showcase innovations. Ultimately, however, Group S was axed along with its older brother and so it was left in history. But upon the Group S rules being written in 1985 albeit in a draft form, a lot of manufacturers jumped on board pretty quickly. They began building prototypes of these Group S races, but of course when the championship was terminated, the prototypes became a lot more valuable than what they were originally thought to be. We therefore have a collection of Group S rally cars that never truly saw the light of day and are generally overshadowed by their Group B cousins. Today, let's take a look at these Group S cars and how they changed from Group B. Toyota did have a presence in Group B, the Celica TCT. However, the TCT was rear wheel drive, thanks large in parts of the fact that it was introduced in 1983 when it was the norm to build rear wheel drive rally cars. When four wheel drive became the norm in the next few years, the TCT faded away and isn't remembered that well. So when Group S was announced, Toyota wanted a fresh start and to turn over a new leaf. Enter the Toyota MR2 triple 2D. This thing does look pretty similar to the regular counterpart until you take a closer look. For example, the width, which is now much wider to encompass wider tire sizes and for better stability. Plus, the iconic pop-up headlights have been replaced with traditional fixed ones, as well as the addition of rally spotlights which both improve aerodynamics. Two engines were also theorised to be in the triple 2D, a 2.1 liter 40 GTA which was used in the TCT and a 2.2 liter Group C prototype, which is apparently where the triple 2D name comes from, MR2 2.2 liter 3.2s. Power ranges were supposedly between 600 brake horsepower and 750 brake horsepower, and the 750 kilogram weight would have made the triple 2 a nippy little monster. Speaking of monster, this prototype was named the Black Monster, based on the fact that the Black Semicol's paint made the color very fierce and very angular. 11 were reportedly built, but with crash tests and other events taking their course, only three remained to day, two black and one white, and tech would care of them. The Ford RS200S is a special story that can't never officially exist, while plans went fairly far with its design, Ford decided not to build any prototype until later in development, which was probably a good thing to retrospect. Other than that, we know it was to feature a brand new gearbox, lighter bodywork, remodeled intercooler and most jarringly, the removal of the protruding air duct from the roof of the car to improve aerodynamics. However, two decades after the demise of Group S, John Wheeler, a cheap designer of the original RS200 and the RS200S, decided to bring the design to life with a specially built replica. First, he bought a moderately damaged rally cross-hours 200 and replaced the bent rear end to have it be returned to better condition. Then work was done to convert the original to the S model, a new wing was added and all the original changes were put into effect. Plus the traditional BDT engine was replaced with a YB engine, which powered the Ford S-Corp Cosworth for a few years in the 1990s, it could supposedly do 485p at cost power and the S was said to be around 90kg lighter than the original. While not completely faithful to the original design, as changes were seen here and there, this is no Frankenstein's monster. Persia was one of the most successful competitors in Group B, so it was a given that they would want a competing Group S. Persia was originally going to go with something along the lines of what Ford did, as they were originally going to simply upgrade their successful 2 or 5. However, the 2 or 5 had a shorter wheelbase than what Persia wanted and even with experimentation on a elongated wheelbase, they couldn't get the 2 or 5 to work under this new structure. So they instead decided to take their brand new 4 or 5, which was released as a standard road going car in 1987. As well as having much better dimensions for what Persia wanted, building a rally version would make for some effective marketing. The team then adapted the 2 or 5 chassis and drivetrain for the new length and the 4 or 5 prototype was born. As well as weighing in near 880kg, it also allowed for a larger fuel tank to be fitted. The 4 or 5 was much more versatile, the engine was also a credit to a 1.9L. However, unlike other Group S prototypes which met the end of their official careers along with the championship, the 4 or 5 T16 actually went on to compete in the Pike's Peacons and National Hill climb and managed a victory. It also meant multiple appearances in heavily modified forms in rally-ready events, with much larger reinforced suspension and a larger fuel tank. It managed to deliver Persia 2 wins in 1989 and 1990 in the Paris de Car Rally. Persia was able to keep their T16 line of races in a competitive form for almost a decade, which isn't too bad. The 130LR was a moderately successful entry into Group B from Scoda. Scoda was intent on improving it and when Group S was announced Scoda only quickened their pace. Originally however, Scoda planned to build a specially modified version of the upcoming Scoda Favourite tour, however you pronounce it. But when the production of the Favourite was delayed, the team decided to refocus their efforts onto the already successful 130, now known as the 130LR Reaver. Why did body kits and tyres were fitted, rear ducts were added for better rear ventilation, rear spoiler became molded into the body, the bonnet was fitted with an air vent to keep the ready at a cool and a lot of other things were added. Alterations were also made to the position of certain elements in the car to help balance out the drastic 40-60 weight ratio in the back of the car. The 1.2-litre engine was also a step up and the 850kg weight was a huge improvement. The car was first tested here in July of 1986 and the car then did some races here and thereafter group S was cancelled, being passed between different owners over the years. Multiple replicas of the Evo have been built but other than that, not much is known. While these prototype are all cool in their own right, there are two specific group S cars that have become truly iconic, even outside of group S. The first of which is the Audi Sport Quattro RS-002. This car should never have truly existed. The prototype was actually built in secrecy without the knowledge of higher ups and even the chairman of Audi. In short, a lot of the team knew that the front engine doubly Quattro would not be able to survive for long. While it was great on fast-straight and corners, slower corners became a problem thanks to the understeer due to the large part of the engine being mounted over the front axle. Mid-engined was the way to go, so they began building these prototype in complete secrecy and test runs were planned to be taken on dirt roads near Salzburg in Austria, but when the press were tipped off, Audi ran for the border to find somewhere else to test the car. Compositely, Audi's Star-Racer Walter Rol could tell almost immediately that the mid-engined Quattro is much faster than the old one. Few pictures remained of this secret prototype. The most notable thing on the car however is the telltale ducts added to the side, but the backlash meant that the mid-engined project had to be dismantled pretty quickly. But another prototype had been made. This one looked radically different to the traditional Quattro design and three were produced. While one was destroyed in another would remain on static display in the museum, one is unaccounted for which, from what I can gather, means that there's still one roaming in the wild. This prototype had very smooth styling and a freakishly large wing, and to many look more like a group C-carber. That's not a bad thing. Then for the 30th anniversary of the final year of Group B, the RS-002 was restored and has since been touring, with Rol occasionally taking the wheel of the car he tested all those years ago. Then there's what is considered the poster child for Group S, the Lancia ECV and all its variants. Even before Group B was banned, the Delta was undergoing major improvements to make it more competitively viable, upgrading the reliability and performance of the gearbox and engine, which we built in the front suspension, shifting the centre of weight were all things on the list, but most importantly was the improvement of the aerodynamics, a particular fault of the original S4. Sidescurses and a retractable flap on the front bumper were considered to be used, but when Group B was cancelled, the project, which was codenamed SEO-4R, was cancelled. But with the prospect of Group S, a new project was started called ECV, which stands for Experimental Composite Vehicle, a lot of the technical innovations from the previous project were brought over, and the resulting car was shown off at the 1986 Belonio Motor Show. Because of the 10 car requirement for homologation, Lancia was able to include some expensive innovations, with a large part of the body being constructed after carbon fibre. The chassis for example also made a large part out of carbon fibre, was 20% lighter than the steel chassis from the S4, while being just as stable. It even supposedly used computer assisted design in its conception, a brand new technology which had only ever been seen in Formula 1 up to this point. The engine also saw some relative changes, with a design that had the turbochargers turn off at different speeds. So at low speeds only one turbo would be functional, but as the speed rose the second turbo would slowly kick in. This meant the engine would work well at low rev ranges, and could do 600 brake horsepower. ECV also featured the aerodynamics from the SEO 4R, with side skirts, a rear diffuser, single head lights, a roof spoiler and side scoops arm making an appearance. The project was well liked and stayed pretty close to the original vision of Group S, a car that would show off the groundbreaking innovations in lightweight chassis and power. And that's not all however, we have the ECV too. It had the same chassis and engine as the first ECV, but the body was wildly different, like what the RS-002 was to the original mid-engine Quattro. Straying away from the sharp almost boxy designs of recent Lancia cars, the body featured a lot of curves and was much more compact. While they were revolutionary in the original car, when the second turbo kicked in, the car had a huge boost of power, which was supposedly uncontrollable, so the ECV2 had smaller turbos. However, due to the ECV2 having the same chassis and engine of the original, and to save cost by not building more, the first ECV had to be dismantled in order to build the ECV2. But on the flip side, a replica of the first ECV was built in 2010 using a standard Lancia beltress for stradale, and now the two ECV brothers stand proud as a monument to group S. I could go on. There are multitude of other group S prototypes that I haven't covered, such as the Mazda RX-7S, the Selti-Bitha bi-motor and the Opel Cadet E4S. If you'd like me to cover these cars, I would be happy to make part two, but to think the cars I covered today were the foundation blocks of group S and what it could have been. Lightware, more powerful and generally some of the best looking cars of the decade, there's no better place to look for crazy cars than the world of the group S prototype. Thanks for watching. I'd also like to give my thanks to the Group B shrine, a website dedicated to uncovering all of the details out group B and Group S. Most if not all of the info presented here today in this video were from them. So if you'd like to learn more about any specific car you've seen in this video, or anything else on the subject, be sure to check them out. Thanks again.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Lou Correa Asks DOJ Official At What Point A Cyber Attack Constitutes A Declaration Of War
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: I recognize myself for five minutes of question. Mr. Wilson, serve first of all, let me thank you for your service. You got a tough job. Defence of our country, our citizens. You have to play 100% defense. You can't let them score. Anyway, former manor. If I can, let me turn to cyber a little bit. Cyber security. Question. At what point does the cyber attack on our nation constitute a declaration of war? We recently had an attack on our federal court system. Brazen, unbelievable. It's a rhetorical question. I don't think you can answer that. But the point is made, which is cyber is an attack on our nation. And it's a deadly attack in many ways. I presume you're concerned with the increasing cyber attacks, threats from Russian, China, and other actors. Yes, absolutely. This committee recently considered legislation that requires American companies to open their hardware and software to third parties, which could allow some of these actors, China, Russia, and others, to have additional access to US consumer data. Doesn't this pose a cyber security risk? So the cyber threat is a vast and complicated one. The Nascar Division, we're focused on nation-state type attacks, particularly as you mentioned, China and Russia. China actually probably is the most significant actor when it comes to cyber-enabled espionage. It is a challenge for both the government, public sector, and the private sector. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Rep. Peters Calls Out House GOP Energy Week as Political Theatre
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Mr. Speaker, the majority is once again choosing to engage in a partisan, unproductive, and unserious messaging exercise that they have dubbed energy week. In 2023, the United States produced more oil and gas than any other country ever, and exported unprecedented amounts of liquefied natural gas to our allies across the world. Simultaneously, 2023 was a record year for combined utility-scale solar, wind, and energy storage installations across the country. These clean energy projects can be found in nearly all congressional districts in all 50 states. My friends on the other side of the aisle claimed to be champions of an all-of-the-above energy strategy, but they're completely silent about these massive accomplishments that are not only driving significant investments to areas across the country, but are producing cheap, clean, American energy. This is probably because so many of these winds were made possible by the historic bills that house Democrats passed last Congress, like the Inflation Reduction Act and the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. I was proud to include in those bills several of my priorities, including combating methane emissions and encouraging the development of transmission infrastructure, by ensuring the federal government has the tools it needs to step in and stop excessive permitting delays. However, the laws we passed last Congress will not be enough. We are facing extraordinary growth in energy demand from electric vehicles, AI, data centers, and the reshoring of domestic manufacturing, again thanks to the efforts and leadership of President Biden and his administration. But we are lagging far behind China, which is dwarfing us in manufacturing, construction of clean energy resources, and the extraction and refining of critical minerals like nickel and cobalt. We need an unprecedented level of clean energy development and deployment to meet our climate goals and avoid catastrophe. If the majority is interested in talking about a long-term energy strategy to maintain affordability and reliability, we need finally to talk about transmission and the grid. And we also need to work on speed. We will still fail if we let all the money we've set aside sit in the bank by making good energy projects wait years for permits to come through and further delays if bad actors and nervous neighbors take them to the court again and again. It's extremely frustrating that during energy week, we are actually taking the time to vote on whether strong regulations on methane emissions are even necessary, or whether oil and gas producers should cover the costs of unplugged or abandoned wells. Are you kidding me? Of course, we need to regulate methane, and of course, oil and gas companies should pay to clean up for the messes that they made. How can Republicans say they support clean energy while simultaneously fighting against common sense regulations on methane and not even engaging in how to expand and upgrade the grid? The bills we're considering this week take us farther away from the solutions to the problems we're facing, and I am proud to oppose every single one of them. Our country prides itself on accomplishing big things together whether it's winning world wars, constructing interstate highway system, or discovering the next big medical breakthrough. We should be voting on my faster act, so transmission lines aren't stuck jumping between local state and federal agencies for the permits they need. We need to thoughtfully streamline the judicial review process for all energy projects so that developers, agencies, and petitioners aren't in limbo for years. We need certainty, not an unreliable and inefficient, inefficient review process, and everything I said about that today can and should be bipartisan. So I will say to my Republican colleagues, let's look beyond just oil and gas, truly invest in all of the above energy strategy that looks to the future instead of of cleaning onto the past. Thank you and I yield back.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Juan Vargas, Congressman
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Congresswoman Vargas, thank you for joining me today. President Obama has pledged to put everything into tighter gun control. He wants universal background checks on anyone trying to buy a gun. He wants to renew all of the assault weapons ban and a 10-round limit to magazines. What do you think of his proposal? And what are his chances of getting it passed? Well, I support him. I support him in each one of those things. I mean, we have to reduce the gun violence in this country. It's unbelievable the amount of violence that we have today. We can compare ourselves to some of these other democracies around the world. Obviously, we have just so much more violence than they do. So I think he has a good shot. Obviously, it'll be tough in some areas because people have believed that it's the second amendment right to have almost any type of weapon. In fact, some of the crazies have to call these guys crazy. Believe they can have nuclear weapons at home. That's for a malicious second amendment. So it'll be hard to negotiate with them. But I think that a lot of us love our kids. We have something wrong with you. And we want to reduce the violence. And we see it out there. So I'm very hopeful. We have some great testimony over in the Senate. Hope we have some opportunities in the Congress to reduce the violence. And I think some of these measures are good. I'd even go further. How would you go further? Well, I think ammunition is one of the things you really have to go. I mean, why don't you have background checks also for ammunition? They're going to do that in California. I think that would be important too. You know, a lot of these people, they may have a weapon, but they didn't have the ammunition. They couldn't go shoot people. So I'd go even further. OK, let's switch gears to immigration reform. It was a big week for the topic with both the Senate and the President putting forth their own proposals. Both plans offer a path to citizenship. But the Senate plan ties it to border security. How feasible is that? Well, I mean, it's a great first step. I mean, let's take it for what it is. Very positive. I mean, when you have everyone saying we have to take a look at all the people that are here undocumented and do something about it. And something that coincides with our history, which is compassion, love, family, and all these things. So it's a very positive first step. Now, there are differences, as you said, the issue of border security. And who's going to be on this commission? Who decides? I mean, is the governor of Arizona the one going to decide? You can't put it in her hands. She'll say there's never enough security. And then these poor people would be second-class citizens forever. They'd never have an opportunity to become a citizen of the US. So I think it's important that you have a process whereby you can become a citizen. And the president has proposed that, I think, in a better way than the Senate. But you know what? It's a great, great step forward. Expanding on the topic of border security, the Senate plan calls for adding more drones to patrol the border. As you know, drones are becoming an increasingly important part of San Diego's economy. And yet, the Department of Homeland Security's own inspector general says that the border drone program has serious management issues. How necessary do you think these drones are to patrol the border? Well, I have to tell you, it almost seems like a science fiction here with all the drones. I've been reading quite a bit about them. And I'm not really excited about the drones. I mean, I think they do have their place, but flying around the border here, I think it can actually do more damage than help. And I do think there's a real problem with them. So I'm not excited about it. I do think that they have their place in other confrontational areas and conflictive territories. But here at home, flying around the border where they can crash into homes and have all sorts of other problems. I'm not in favor of that. I don't think it helps. The House Republicans have agreed to extend the government's borrowing authority for another three months. That means that this debt-sealing fight is coming back at the end of March. Meanwhile, new figures show that the economy actually contracted in the last three months of last year. Can the United States afford this fight to come up every couple of months? No, I didn't vote for it. I thought it was ridiculous. I mean, one more gimmick, another three months down the road, we fight again. This only hurts our economy. I was one of the few people in Congress that voted against it. You can't create these crises. These crises really is what brings our economy down because you have to have confidence. Before we wrap up here, I want to touch on Santa No 3. As you know, Southern California Edison wants to reopen the plant at reduced capacity, 70 percent. Cities and the San Diego School District is calling for a trial-like hearing in which Edison is basically put on the stand and required to offer evidence that the plant is safe to reopen and cross-examined. What do you think about this? Well, I saw the Energy Constance Development Committee when I was in the assembly when the lights were going off in California. We actually put people under oath and found out what in the world went on. So it's not a bad idea as long as the right people are asking the question and it doesn't become a... Would you consider the right people? People who know what they're talking about. Instead of it becoming a road show and just politics, you know, get experts in there to ask them true questions. Is it really safe? You know, do you really have this under control? And if not why are you firing it up makes no sense. The only reason they want to do this is because they want to be able to get some money. And if it's vacant for a long time, they actually can't recoup their investment. So that's really the issue. One Vargas, thank you for coming on the program. It's a pleasure. Thank you for inviting me.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Rep. Juan Vargas on Comprehensive Immigration Reform
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: The chair recognizes the gentleman from California, Mr. Vargas, for five minutes. I think Mr. Speaker has been at his consent to address the House. Without objection. Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker. Mr. Speaker, I rise in favor of immigration reform, comprehensive immigration reform. I'd like to thank my colleague from Illinois that spoke earlier about his experience in saying that he believes in comprehensive immigration reform I do too. I just wish that when he was asked or when he asked the Board of Patrol agent, if there was one thing that you could bring back to Congress, one thing, what would it be? I wish that that gentleman would have said his Bible, because that's what he should have said. Bring your Bible. That will give you the best guidance. Bring your Bible. And I believe, Mr. Speaker, I'm allowed to read from the Bible. Is that correct? No one will come and tackle me. I'm new at this, my first year here, and I hope I'm not violating any law, but if I am, I'm going to do it anyway. And I would like to read from Matthew 25, because Matthew 25 speaks to the judgment, and I think it's very important for us to read this section, and even though my mom gave to me this Bible some time ago with giant print, I still need glasses now. And it reads like this, when the Son of Man comes in his glory, escorted by all the angels of heaven, he will sit upon his royal throne, and all the nations will be assembled before him. Then he will separate them into two groups as a shepherd-separate sheep from goats. The sheep he will place on his right hand, the goats on his left. The king will say to those on his right, come, you have my father's blessing, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the creation of the world, for I was hungry, and you gave me food. I was thirsty, and you gave me drink. I was a stranger, and you welcomed me. I was a stranger, and you welcomed me. Who is the stranger? Who is the stranger among us that we welcome? I'll tell you who the stranger is among us who we welcome. The stranger is the wife of the soldier that we spoke to three weeks ago here in Washington. When he came and he testified and said, I'm not afraid of dying in Afghanistan, or I racked, I've been on three tours of duty. What I'm afraid is that my wife will get deported because she's undocumented, and then who will take care of my children? She is the stranger, the soldier's wife. Who is the stranger? Who is the stranger among us? Who is this least among us? I'll tell you who it is. It's the child and the parents who are here where the child is born here. He's an American citizen, but the parents weren't so the parents can get deported, and you break the family apart. And we deport the parents, and we don't know what happens to the children because they go to strangers. We break this family. Who's the stranger? Those parents, that child, and how we treat them is how we're going to be judged. And we have an opportunity here before us. And I'm very, very thankful now for the churches in this country. The Catholic Church for many years has been saying, we need humane, comprehensive immigration reform. They've said it loud and clear. And now the evangelical churches are out there saying the same thing. God bless them. And I know that they're praying. I know my parish is praying. We all open our hearts to this. And I have to tell you, I haven't been here long, but I do get the opportunity to pray with my colleagues on the Republican side. And they are great people with great hearts. And I hope that God speaks to them at this point in time and says, the stranger is the soldier's wife. The stranger is the child whose parents are going to be ripped away from. He is, in fact, the people that die crossing the border because they want a better life for themselves. Those are the strangers. And we're going to be judged. We're going to be judged on how we treat them. So we have an opportunity here. But also, step me apart from that people say, but it's illegal. What they've done is illegal. You know, the law is interesting. I happen to be a lawyer. And there's two ways to look at the law. There's the law that says it's mollum, per se. It's bad or evil in itself. Mollum per se in itself. Murder is mollum per se. It's always evil. It's always wrong to kill. On the other side, you have mollum prohibitum. What is mollum prohibitum? Mollum prohibitum means it's bad or wrong or illegal because we prohibit it. For example, if you drive 56 miles an hour in a 55 mile an hour zone, you've broken the law. Have you done anything illegal? Yes, you have. Have you done anything immoral? No. The road was built to go faster than that. Your car was. The brakes are good. You have violated the law. What do we often do? We change the law and we say 55 miles an hour doesn't make any sense. We change it to 60 or 65 or 70. I've been through Texas now. It's 75 there. California, we only have 70. Why because the law doesn't make any sense? Our immigration law doesn't make any sense. So yes, they've broken the law, but a law that doesn't make any sense. So let's change the law. Let's open our hearts. Let's take this Bible. Let's take a look and see what it says to us. And what it will say is this, that how we treat the stranger is how we are going to be judged as a nation. Mr. Speaker, thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Senator Vargas Budget Floor Speech (AB 98)
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Thank you, Mr. President. It's interesting when we talk about the voters and the voters' wills and what the voters want. I think John Adams was the one who said it that facts are stubborn things. So I took a look at a little bit of the facts in California. These are some facts. Back in 1902, this senate floor was populated with 34 Republicans and only six Democrats. The floor on the other side had and the assembly had 60 Republicans and only 20 Democrats. In 1912, interestingly, there were 28 Republicans and there were four Republican and Labor Union Party and eight Democrats. In the assembly, there were 69 Republicans and 11 Democrats. In 1932, on this floor, there were 35 Republicans, only four Democrats and there was a vacancy. In the assembly, there were 73 Republicans and only seven Democrats. Now we moved to more modern times. In 1972, there were only 19 Republicans and there were 21 Democrats in this house. In the other house, there were 36 Republicans, there were 43 Democrats and one vacancy. In 1992, there were 13 Republicans on this floor, 25 Democrats, one independent and one vacancy. In the other house, there were 32 Republicans and 48 Democrats. In 2002, after redistricting once again, there were 14 Republicans on this floor, 25 Democrats and one vacancy. In the assembly, there were 29 Republicans, there were 50 Democrats and one vacancy. So what do you see there? You see the voters speaking. What are opinions, whether we are the ones that carry out the voters' wills, that somehow, the voters are the ones that get to make the decisions? And it's very interesting how we've gone from 1902 from 34 Republicans on this floor to 15 and dwindling. And I do think that after the next election, the Republicans will be punished once again by the voters, because they don't listen to the people. Once again, the party will shrink and continue to shrink. Not my opinion, they're the stubborn facts. I remember spending six years in the assembly hearing over and over and over again how the public, the voters were going to punish the Democrats in the next election. The governor who was elected was a Democrat, lieutenant governor Democrat. You don't have to go down the list, you know every statewide constitutional officer, every one of them is now a Democrat, because the Republicans are not paying attention to the voters. Instead, you're paying attention to a very small but very vocal part of your party that says, net, net, net. It's time to change. It's time to look at what do the people want. I say this because remember the Wigs, remember the Federalist Party, parties that disappeared. Unless the Republicans in California start to understand the needs of the people, they're going to go the way of the Wigs, the way of the Federalist. They've shrunk and they're shrinking and they're going to disappear. Instead, everyone takes a look at the own interest in the very small districts as opposed to the corporate need of the state. I hope that changes. And this budget that we're going to pass today, I'm not happy about it. I'm not happy about it at all. It's not my vision. It's a very difficult budget. We do violence to the courts when we do these cuts. We especially do injustice to our children in the schools, to the poor and the elderly. But this is all we can do with a majority that's not a super majority. But that won't be for long because these numbers, these facts are stubborn. Not my opinion, their history, their facts. And I hope that in fact you start listening to the people. Allow them to vote on important issues like this. Allow them to do that. Otherwise, your numbers will continue to shrink. Thank you Mr. President.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: From National City to Washington DC: Juan Vargas talks about his time in politics and his Hispanic H
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: He is one of the most recognized faces in local politics, spending his childhood in the 51st congressional district that he's now representing for almost a decade. Juan Vargas says there are a lot of things that have changed in San Diego since he was a kid. That includes the always growing number of Latinos in political office. I sat down with him during this Hispanic Heritage Month for a look back on his life and career. I think it's fantastic. When I first got elected, I basically was it. People always used to ask me to go on TV to speak Spanish because I was the only Spanish speaker when it was anything related to Latino heritage month or anything. It was me because there were no other people. That's changed dramatically. Juan Vargas was born in San Diego and grew up in National City. At a time it had a true small town vibe right down to the National City Fair. His neighborhood was mostly Latino. I grew up speaking Spanish in San Diego. My first language was Spanish. It wasn't even though I was born and raised here. Our little uncle, if everybody spoke Spanish. Vargas is one of ten children. His father came to the U.S. from Mexico as part of the Bracero program, working on a chicken ranch. I think I was probably thirteen and I was digging a ditch with my father working in planning trees and in landscape. He said, son, are you enjoying what you're doing? I said, no, dad, I'm not. And he goes, get an education. Is that? Yeah. No, that's what I want to do. Vargas may not have known he'd end up in Congress, but he did have an idea. He'd end up wearing a suit and tie to work after a chance meeting. My mom didn't know the law and she thought that they were going to lose their kids because of this accident. And we had a volunteer lawyer who was a Latino. They came and told us, ultimately, lady, you're a bad driver. You're not a bad mother. You're not going to lose your kids. And I looked up to him. I just thought, wow, it's the first Latino I had ever met in the United States with a Sudan. I'd never met one with a Sudan. And also, he kind of became the image of who I wanted to be. You can be anything you want in this country, in this country, even though you're poor, you can do anything you want. He graduated from the University of San Diego in 1983 at this ceremony. He'd add a master's from Fordham and then a law degree from Harvard. Juan Vargas first took office on the San Diego City Council in 1993. He was the only Latino on the council at the time. That was the first time he sat down with CBS 8 for a Hispanic Heritage Month story. There were times, certainly, when I was growing up that I felt I had to prove myself. Had to work a little harder, had some questioning about my abilities because I was a Latino. Vargas moved to State Assembly in 2000, State Senate in 2010, and Congress representing the 51st District since 2013. He is proud of his record and representation. I never did anything that I'm ashamed of just the opposite. I think I've behaved myself well and comported myself in a way that is appropriate. And so I feel good about that. Feel good about where my community is here in San Diego. Hispanic Heritage Month has become a big celebration. And for Vargas, it's a chance to appreciate progress. I think the biggest thing, at least for me, about Hispanic Heritage Month is that you can be proud of who you are as a Latino. Growing up, as I did, people would call you names and lots of other things that were very negative. They don't do that anymore. People are respectful, but they're proud of the diversity. And that's what I would tell them. I mean, I think we've come a long way in this community. I think we've come a long way in this country to accept people as they are. They're backgrounds. And I think that's a fabulous thing. Do you have any special memories about Hispanic Heritage Month? Now, when you're growing up, it was a week. And then, well, into your adulthood, it became Hispanic Heritage Month. What are your memories about it? It is interesting going to Old Town. It was kind of a treat for us. Old Town was kind of expensive for a family like us to go to. But it was always a nice place. So we go to Old Town. We go to one of those Mexican restaurants. My mom and dad really enjoyed it. And before it was us, Latino celebrating this now, it's like everyone celebrating something. It's fun. I think it really has transcended just the Latino community. I think maybe Corona did that because of all the advertising who knows. But it is funny because I think that now it's something that's pretty universal to everybody. So, whether driven by advertising or integration, Hispanic Heritage is celebrated by so many in San Diego in so many ways. And Vargas is proud to be a part of that and of a growing melting pot. And that's one of the things I love about San Diego. We do try hard. I mean, we do try to integrate everyone in our community. We do try to get along. I think we do. I think we have a very rich culture. Not only Latinos, but Irish, Italians, African Americans, of course, Filipinos. And I think that makes it a wonderful community. Congressman Vargas says his parents are very supportive. He had an uncle who kind of discouraged him for pursuing his career and his education and his dreams. And his parents said, no, it's America. You can be anything you want to be. And he did. He became that. He is the American dream. You were saying it during the story. I love, you know what I love, all the old footage through the years at CBS 8 has covered everywhere. He's back. One of the things we have, we have a long institutional memory. I have to thank Barbara Neilson. She's our archives editor. She helped me dig through. We had to go through a lot of stuff to find some of those older images. And I also want to thank Colleen Murphy who edited that. But we have this bank that we like to reach into it and make some withdrawals on once in a while. And it was fun doing it. It was fun to look at it. It's incredible. Wow, the history.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Rep. DeGette speaks in support of Dreamers at Denver rally
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: You know, this is a really important rally, but you don't need to me to tell you that. Most of the immigrants who live in Denver have lived here most of their lives. There are friends in our neighbors, there are kids, teachers and their coaches. They are valuable members of our communities and none of them, none of them, ever, deserve to have to spend their lives worrying about if someone is going to take them and deport them to another country. Especially our dreamers. As we just heard from Alejandro, our dreamers are special. Most of them came here at a very young age. They grew up here. They went to school here. They helped our community grow in countless ways. We have more than 800,000 dreamers across our country, including thousands who are right here in the Denver area. And you know what? Each one of those dreamers deserves the best we can give them in this community and this country. I want to tell you, instead of providing them simple protection, we should be providing them a path to citizenship. Instead of forcing them to live in fear, we should be helping our dreamers to succeed. Instead of ripping their families apart, we should be helping them bring their families together because that's what we do here in America. Now I want to talk about Maria who came here to the U.S. at the age of five. These kids are not a threat to our nation. These kids are our nation. We better realize that. I'm here for two reasons. Number one, to tell this Supreme Court to do the right thing and to uphold DACA. But beyond that, I'm here to say it's been nearly six months since the U.S. House of Representatives passed the legislation to protect these kids and provide them the path to citizenship, the DREAM Act. And Congressman Crow, who's standing here, Congressman Neguse and Congressman ProMutter, we all voted for and co-sponsored the DREAM Act and we are so proud of that. But, like I said, it's been six months. We need to pass the DREAM Act in the Senate. We need to put it on President Trump's desk. So it's two things we need to do. partisan_rally_speeches.title: Weekly Democratic Address -- Congresswoman Diana DeGette
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Hello, I'm Congresswoman Diana Dugette from Colorado. As a senior member of the House Committee with jurisdiction over health care policy, I've played a leading role in the development of comprehensive health reform in this country. I helped shepherd the Affordable Care Act into law eight years ago, and since then, I've proudly been at the forefront of the fight to defend American's health care from the many badly misguided Republican efforts to repeal the law and the historic protections it provides. After the ACA passed, finally forbidding insurers from discriminating against or denying coverage to Americans with pre-existing conditions, the GOP spent eight years crusading to repeal the law, even forcing a government shutdown at one point to make their case. Last year, after 217 House Republicans voted for their terrible repeal bill to take away Americans' health care, the effort failed by just one vote in the Senate. Had Republicans succeeded, they would have devastated health care coverage in this country. Millions of Americans would have lost their coverage or been forced to pay more for it. Under Americans would have faced what the AARP called an age tax, meaning they could be charged up to five times as much for coverage as younger ones. And protections for the 130 million people with pre-existing conditions would have been gutted. After failing in the Congress, Republicans turned to the court with a cruel lawsuit to strike down protections for pre-existing conditions. And the Republican leadership in Congress continues to introduce other bills that still would undermine the ability of the millions of Americans with pre-existing conditions to get affordable and comprehensive health insurance. In August, Republican Senators introduced a bill with a big loophole for health insurance companies that essentially would let them exclude pre-existing conditions from coverage. Our bill would allow insurers to charge those with costlier health conditions much more for their insurance, making health coverage unaffordable for families with loved ones with pre-existing conditions across America. House members soon followed suit with a similar bill. But even after voting to destroy protections for pre-existing conditions and pushing new legislative and legal assaults, Republicans are now falsely claiming that they are taking steps to preserve these protections. It's ironic that Republicans have said they support keeping pre-existing condition protections while continuing their relentless assault on American's health care. Worse yet, Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell admitted that if his party has the votes in Congress next year, they'll try again to repeal the ACA altogether. And President Trump said the same thing last month. Democrats have a different agenda for Congress, a Congress that works for the people instead of a Congress obsessed with destroying American's health care. We want to lower health care costs and the price of prescription drugs. We want to raise wages and drive strong economic growth by rebuilding America. And we want to clean up corruption to make Washington work for you. Rather than attacking the health care of Americans with pre-existing conditions, I urge my Republican colleagues to actually work across the aisle to strengthen America's health care system. Republicans should work with Democrats on bipartisan improvements that would reduce premiums and deductibles, increase price transparency, and access to care providing relief from high drug prices. The public expects no less. Thank you.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: Diana DeGette Remarks at 2012 Democratic National Convention
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: Friends and fellow delegates, my husband and I have raised two accomplished daughters who we taught, but my parents and grandparents taught me and my three sisters. My sisters and I were encouraged to choose the direction of our lives. We became a congresswoman, a stand-home mom, a filmmaker and a journalist, and Lena and I taught our children that they could rise to even greater heights. They could become surgeons, CEOs, Supreme Court justices, Secretary of State, and even President of the United States. We didn't teach our daughters that they were second-class citizens. With proposal after proposal, Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan want to make women second-class citizens again. We will not let that happen. As a fourth generation, Colorado, I believe that our Western spirit is an inspiration for what makes America great. Our learner stands strong in our defensive individual rights and women's equality. Colorado will celebrate its 120th anniversary of granting women the right to vote, the very first state in the nation to do so. The achievements we've achieved did not come easily. Many oppose the advance of women into new roles and responsibilities. They even oppose our right to vote. But working together, we have established our rightful place in our American Republic. Even today though, there are still many battles to be won. Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan would have us fighting to defend old gains all over again. More and more in this economy, the women are the family breadwinners. We are managing our family budgets, struggling to pay health care bills, and facing the challenge of saving for college. We feel it in our paychecks when we receive only $0.77 for every dollar a man earns. President Obama understands how unfair this is. That's why the very first bill he signed was the Lilly Ledbetter Act to strengthen a woman's right to demand equal pay for doing the exact same job. But look what the Romney Ryan ticket would do. Cut PAL grants which make college affordable. Repeal the Affordable Care Act that finally prohibits discrimination by insurance companies when they charge women more than men for health insurance. The Romney Ryan ticket promises to slash plan parenthood funding that helps women get affordable cancer screening and family planning services. Romney and Ryan support the so-called personhood amendment that would ban many forms of birth control, would ban all abortions even in the cases of rape, incest, or to save a mother's life. Ban in vitro fertilization which helps families have children of their own. And it would even ban embryonic stem cell research which holds the promise to cure so many diseases. But although these restrictions on women's rights are all Republican ideas and even in their platform, my friends across the aisle now try to change the subject. It's the economy they cry and you know what? They're right. When they break the guarantee of Medicare, it will hurt women and families right in the pocketbook. When they allow insurance companies to deny coverage, they solely on the pre-existing condition of being a woman. It hurts women and families right in the pocketbook. When they take away the guarantee of coverage for mammograms, for cervical cancer screenings in the Affordable Care Act, it will hurt women and families right in the pocketbook. And when they deny women access to birth control so that we can plan to have our children, it hits women and families right in the pocketbook. Reproductive freedom means economic freedom. And that's what this debate is all about. In short, the Romney Ryan ticket would reverse more than a century of hard fought progress for women. Mr. Romney, Mr. Ryan, the women of America have a message for you. We're not going back. We're going forward. Forward with the President who understands and dispends the rights and interests of America women. Forward with the President who believes in economic opportunity, equal pay for equal work. Forward with our President Barack Obama. Forward with our President Barack Obama.

partisan_rally_speeches.title: 2016 Teacher of the Year Jahana Hayes
partisan_rally_speeches.transcript: At this time, we will hear from a very special person. We will hear from the 2016 National Teacher of the Year. Hayes says it is of no benefit to anyone if a student achieves high grades and tremendous academic success if they have no desire or knowledge on how to help others. Hayes cites her personal experience as her reason for becoming a teacher. She is the first in her family to attend college and gratefully recalls teachers in her life who led her borrow books to learn at home. Today, she passes on this work by promoting cultural awareness and developing service learning curriculum for her high school and her community. Hayes also believes that students need role models who are reflective of themselves. How true. To that end, she has helped secure grants to promote education as a career, especially from minority candidates. I am pleased and honored to introduce Johanna Hayes, a 2016 national teacher of the year. Please give her a warm tigger. Welcome. Thank you. Thank you. Good morning. Good morning. Good morning. Good morning. Thank you so much for having me and for the PTA's commitment to the Teacher of the Year program. I don't know where Connecticut is. I know you're here. There they are. Thank you, Connecticut. Jim Ackamondo, who has been so tremendously supportive throughout this entire process. The Connecticut PTA actually gave my class a grant. Every year, I take my kids to build homes around the country. Went to Dallas, Texas this year with Habitat for Humanity, and Texas. And the PTA helped support that. And oh, I can't. I have to thank my new friends from Ohio. I really quickly just serendipitously last night I came in, and I'm in the lobby just trying to collect myself. I've been traveling all day. I was in Washington all last week. I've been on the road for the last couple weeks. And these women kept coming over to me offering me cake. It was very random, very weird. Each one of them separately, please come have cake. Would you like to join us for cake? They had no idea who I was. And then finally, I asked them, are you guys just traveling with cake? And they thought about it. And they said, yes, yes we are. So thank you. The cake was amazing. The conversation was even better. And they've adopted me. So I have people from Connecticut and people from Ohio bookending me while I speak this morning. I think I want to start with a story, just to tell you a little bit about who I am and help you understand why I truly appreciate and understand the commitment of parent teacher organizations. I was raised by my grandmother, my whole life. Well, not my whole life, my middle years. My mother was an incredible mother. Very supportive, very domestic, a wonderful mother, until the point where she wasn't. My mother struggled with addiction in my middle years. And my brother and I went to live with my grandmother, who was also raising my three cousins. So the five of us lived in this home. And my grandmother was a tremendous provider. She took care of us. She cared about us. She worked very hard to support us. And when it came to school though, my grandmother just said two things to us. Don't let me get a call from the school. And don't bring home any bad grades. That was the extent of her involvement in school. And we knew exactly what that meant. So none of us ever got calls home from school. And none of us ever brought home bad grades. And I thought that that was enough. That what my grandmother was doing for us in relationship to school was enough. Until the day where I overheard my teacher, tell another teacher that my grandmother didn't care about me. You can imagine how that felt. It was the night before it was parents' night. And we used to put all of our work in a folder for our parents to take with them when they came to visit. Well, my grandmother never came to parents' night because she didn't drive. And she struggled with a lot of health issues and she had the five of us at home. So my folder was always on my desk the next day. So I'm trying to rush in early to get it so that no one would notice that my parent was probably the only parent who didn't show up. And I overheard my teacher, tell another teacher in the hallway, those parents don't care. They never come to anything. And I kind of choke up even today when I think about that because 30 years later, the razor sharpness of that comment still bothers me. I still see her standing there. I still smell the perfume she wore when she made that comment because I was confused. How can you say that my grandmother doesn't care about me when just this morning, I woke up and she had dough rolled out on the kitchen table and she had a soup can making biscuits for us to eat before we went to school. Every morning we had a hot breakfast. Every day we came home and our laundry was done, our house was taken care of, all of our needs were met. So for my teacher to say that my grandmother didn't care because she didn't come to a parent teacher event was troubling for me. And I really didn't know what that meant or how to process that. So I've always been haunted by the idea that there's a perception that the level of commitment that a person has to a school directly relates to how much they care about their children. When I became a mother, not too long later, I was always very careful about that. I'm going to make sure I go to school. I'm going to make sure I'm active. I'm going to make sure I'm involved. I had my daughter when I was 17. I got pregnant in high school. It took everything in me to finish school. Everything in me that supported my family, my community, my friends to get me through college. And I remember very carefully, there was an event happening at the school and I couldn't attend. And I was crippled by the fact that my daughter's teacher might make a comment about me, the way a teacher had made a comment about my grandmother many years ago. And that just bothered me. I had just started a job. I was working second shift, the 3-to-11 shift. And I was in what they called the working test period. And in this working test period, you couldn't take any days off for anything. So I went back and forth. I have to go to the school. But if I take the day off, I'm going to lose this very good job that I've just secured. I didn't go to the event. And I struggled with that. I called a friend. I was calling around my aunt, my mother, my cousin, can anybody go just so that my daughter will have somebody there. So her teacher will know that her family cares about her. Today, I am a teacher. I'm happily married. My husband, we both are college educated, have amazingly active careers and work lives. My husband is a homicide detective. The hours for that are crazy. So he really has no set hours. And this new teacher life that I've entered into. And I still struggle with not being at coffee hour in the morning or not being at parent's events. Now, here I am, the ideal family. Two parent household, college educated, employed. This is what, in my mind, I think the perfect family looks like. And still, I'm not attending events at school. I say all of that to say the amount that a person enters a school building, or the time that they spend engaged with the school, does not directly connect to how much they care about their child. If you have any question about whether the PTA is still relevant, whether the PTA is still necessary, I would say that my grandmother thinks you're relevant, my daughter thinks you're relevant, I think you're relevant. Because just because a person is not there or is not present doesn't mean that they don't have something to add to the conversation. No meaningful conversation about education. I don't care if it's standards, test scores, compensation, building facilities, school lunches can take place without the input of parents, families, and communities. So as a teacher, I carry that with me all the time. And I try to put structures in place so that no child will ever feel embarrassed in my classroom about the family they come from. That no parent will ever be ashamed of the amount of commitment they bring to the table. And no school will be a place where parents, family, students feel unwelcome. Not everybody, either knows how has the ability or the time energy effort to put into what we expect as teachers. I get it in a perfect world and an ideal place. We would enter into a dialogue and have conversations where we're both supporting students, but people are supporting students in very different ways. And I think we have to remember that. If we want different results, then we have to do things differently. No longer can we put up a flyer that says we're having a meeting at the school on Thursday, please attend. That is not what parent engagement looks like. As I'll tell you what, my grandmother would never attend that meeting. There is no bus in the neighborhood where we grew up. And she didn't drive. But it doesn't mean that she didn't care about me. It doesn't mean that she wasn't doing her part at home to support the education I was receiving at school. We have to look at this through a very different lens. In my school, I've developed programs where I am out in the community. I get it. I am so crippled by the fact that parents can attend parents night that I go the weeks leading up to parents night to our, we have several community centers. And I have open air conversations is what I tell them. And I say to parents, I am in your neighborhood tonight. If you want to talk to me about your child, this is where I'll be. I have just started using social media as a platform. In my district, they say we don't want anyone using social media. But this is the world we live in. If we want to engage parents, if we want to connect with people, then we have to do it on their level with the skills and abilities that they possess. There is a very traditional way of looking at education. And if we lived in a very traditional world with traditional children and traditional families, that would work. But when you work in a school and live in a world where you have students where the parents English is not their first language, where you have students who are living in foster care, where you have students who are being raised by an aunt and grandmother, a cousin and uncle because their parent is incarcerated or they're working at night and going to school in the morning and you have all these different dynamics. Then that structure that we have in place where parents work from seven to three in meetings take place at five on Thursday nights and kids go home to two parents all the time. If we continue to operate within those parameters, you will be talking to yourself because there's about 3% of the population that fits into that box. My son asked me all the time, how come you never come to coffee hour? And I said, because I have to work. How come you've got to work all the time because you have to eat? Well, I don't eat that much because he still doesn't understand what that means. So I reach out to his teacher all the time, but that's because I know how to. Not everybody knows how to navigate this system. We use so many acronyms in education that a parent would need a translator to even understand the conversations that we're having. I'm the national teacher of the year. I say that because for anyone who doesn't know any better, they would think that I know about education. I'm very well versed. And just last week I'm sitting at a conference and I'm turning to my colleagues every third word. What does that mean? What are they talking about? L.E.A. I see it. What is happening right now? And I know I am in the field. So imagine how a parent feels. Imagine how a grandparent feels with a fifth grade education who can cook anything without a cookbook who's walking in a school, having a conversation with people in a language that she doesn't understand and nobody stops to explain it to her. Imagine how that made her feel. We cannot spend the last decade bashing this profession and then wondering why nobody wants to come in and talk to us. I'm sorry. It just gets me so fired up. I live on a cul-de-sac and we have a dog and I'm like the worst dog ever because no, really. I just let the dog out in the morning because I'm tired. But she's a really good dog. All the kids love her so she goes to all the houses and the kids that are waiting for the bus they pet her and I'm like send her home when she's not. And there's one house on my street. Everybody has this neighbor. Get off of my lawn. She's yelling at the dog and I see her. So I step back thinking that maybe she'll think the dog got out and I didn't let the dog out. But what I noticed was after a couple days, weeks, whatever, the dog visits everyone when he gets to her house, off of the grass into the street goes around her property to the next house. Even a dog knows not to call somewhere where they're not welcome. Even a dog knows not to continue to go somewhere where people don't treat them kindly. Please help me understand why a parent would want to continue to go to a school where they don't feel welcome, where they're not having good experiences, where there's negative interaction and you're telling them that you value their input. Stop telling them. Show them that you value their input. Over the next year and perhaps for the last decade and throughout my career, I have operated in a way that would be respectful of my grandmother. I have always been mindful to frame my thoughts, my responses, my content as if I was speaking with or dealing with my grandma because my grandmother loved us in a way that I cannot tell you about but I know what it feels like. She couldn't articulate that. She couldn't verbalize that but she showed us every day. So to exclude her from the conversation, based on those things is not fair, it's not who we are, it's not what education is about. Be purposeful in your interactions. Thank you.

We're obligated to remember our bonds with the good people of Pacific islands to rebuild these bonds and to work with them to defeat the attack on their freedoms, and quite frankly, our strategic interests. Secretary Clinton break the then president of the Federal States of Micronesia, David Panamelo, released three letters over the last two years that laid out in detail the PRC's comprehensive and pernicious political warfare against the Federal States of Micronesia and other islands as well. Mr. Chairman, I'd like to end those letters into the record. Mike. Thank you. The letters, by the way, the title of the article letter to company's letters is Micronesia's President Wright's bombshell letter on China's political warfare, authored by Cleopascal and the diplomat. So his letters were a cry for help from us. In his March 23 letter, President Panamelo wrote, as a result of aggressive political warfare on his country by Beijing, he was in well-advanced negotiations with Taipei to switch his country's recognition back to Taiwan. This would have been a huge win for the free world, adding people of Micronesia, but it didn't happen. When you explained to me what the State Department did to assist the Federal States of Micronesia Taipei negotiations at that time? Congressman, I don't know if I can respond specifically to what happened right at that time, but what I can say is absolutely agree with you about the centrality of our partnerships with our Pacific Island friends.
